University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: (base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge
(base) That the ladyes made / at the brennynge
(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
(base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
(base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure
(base) After the bataille / and disconfiture
(base) And so bifel / in the taas they founde
(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde
(base) Two yonge knyghtes / liggynge by and by
(base) Bothe in oon armes / wroght ful richely
(base) Of whiche two / Arcita highte that oon
(base) And that oother knyght highte Palamon
(base) Nat fully quyk / ne fully deed they weere
(base) But by hir Cote armures / and by hir geere
(base) The heraudes / knewe hem best in special
(base) As they that weren / of the blood roial
(base) Of Thebes / and of sustren two yborn
(base) Out of the taas / the pilours han hem torn
(base) And han hem caryed / softe vnto the tente
(base) Of Theseus / and he ful soone hem sente
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon
(base) He took his oost / and hom he ryt anoon
(base) With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
(base) And there he lyueth / in ioye / and in honour
(base) Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And in a tour / in angwissh and in wo
(base) Dwellen this Palamon / and eek Arcite
(base) For euere moore / ther may no gold hem quyte
(base) ¶ This passeth yeer by yeer / and day by day
(base) Til it fil ones / in a morwe of May
(base) That Emelye / that fairer was to seene
(base) Than is the lilie / vpon his stalke greene
(base) And fressher than the May / with floures newe
(base) For with the Rose colour stroof hir hewe
(base) I noot which was / the fairer of hem two
(base) Er it were day / as was hir wone to do
(base) She was arysen / and al redy dight
(base) For May wol haue / no slogardye a nyght
(base) The sesoun pryketh / euery gentil herte
(base) And maketh it out of his sleep to sterte
(base) And seith arys / and do thyn obseruance
(base) This maketh Emelye / haue remembrance
(base) To doon honour to May / and for to ryse
(base) Yclothed was she fressh / for to deuyse
(base) Hir yelow heer / was broyded in a tresse
(base) Bihynde hir bak a yerde long I gesse
(base) And in the gardyn / at the sonne vp riste
(base) She walketh vp and doun / and as hir liste
(base) She gadreth floures / party white and rede
(base) To make / a subtil gerland for hir hede
(base) And as an Aungel / heuenysshly she soong
(base) ¶ The grete tour / that was so thikke and strong
(base) Which of the Castel / was the chief dongeoun
(base) Ther as the knyghtes / weren in prisoun
(base) Of whiche I tolde yow / and tellen shal
(base) Was euene ioynant to the gardyn wal
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ther as this Emelye / hadde hir pleyyng
(base) Bright was the sonne / and cleer / in that mornyng
(base) And Palamon / this woful prisoner
(base) As was his wone / by leue of his Gailler
(base) Was risen / and romed in a chambre anheigh
(base) In which / he al the noble Citee seigh
(base) And eek the gardyn / ful of braunches greene
(base) Ther as / the fresshe Emelye the sheene
(base) Was in hir walk / and romed vp and down
(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon
(base) Gooth in the chambre / romyng to and fro
(base) And to hymself / compleynyng of his wo
(base) That he was born / ful ofte he seyde allas
(base) And so bifel / by auenture / or cas
(base) That thurgh a wyndow / thikke of many a barre
(base) Of Iren greet and square as any sparre
(base) He caste his eye / vpon Emelya
(base) And therwithal he bleynte / and cryde . A .
(base) As thogh / he stongen weere / vnto the herte
(base) ¶ And with that cry / Arcite anoon vp sterte
(base) And seyde cosyn myn / what eyleth thee
(base) That art so pale / and deedly on to see
(base) Why cridestow / who hath thee doon offence
(base) For goddes loue / tak al in pacience
(base) Oure prison / for it may noon oother be
(base) Fortune / hath yeuen vs this aduersitee
(base) Som wikked aspect or disposicioun
(base) Of Saturne / by som constellacioun
(base) Hath yeuen vs this / althogh we hadde it sworn
(base) So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
(base) We mote endure it this is the short and playn
(base) This Palamoun answerde / and seyde agayn
(base) ¶ Cosyn for sothe / of this opinioun
(base) Thow hast a vayn ymaginacioun
(base) This prisoun / caused me noght to crye
(base) But I was hurt right now / thurgh out myn Iye
(base) In to myn herte / that wol my bane be
(base) The fairnesse / of that lady that I se
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Yond in the gardyn / romen to and fro
(base) Is cause / of al my cryyng and my wo
(base) I noot wher she be womman / or goddesse
(base) But Venus / is it soothly / as I gesse
(base) And therwithal / on knees down he fil
(base) And seyde / Venus if it be thy wil
(base) Yow in this gardyn / thus to transfigure
(base) Bifore me / sorweful wrecched creature
(base) Out of this prisoun / help that we may scape
(base) And if so be / my destynee be shape
(base) By eterne word / to dyen in prisoun
(base) Of oure lynage / haue som compassioun
(base) That is so lowe ybroght by tirannye
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite gan espye
(base) Where as this lady / romed to and fro
(base) And with that sighte / hir beautee hurte hym so
(base) That if that Palamon / was wounded soore
(base) Arcite is hurt . as muche as he / or moore
(base) And with a syk / . he seyde pitously
(base) The fresshe beautee / sleeth me sodeynly
(base) Of hire / that rometh in the yonder place
(base) And but I haue / hir mercy / and hir grace
(base) That I may seen hire / at the leeste weye
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ This Palamon / whan he tho wordes herde
(base) Despitously / he loked / and answerde
(base) Wheither seistow this / in ernest or in pley
(base) ¶ Nay quod Arcite / in ernest by my fey
(base) God help me so / me list ful yuele pleye
(base) This Palamon / gan knytte his browes tweye
(base) ¶ It were to thee quod he / no greet honour
(base) For to be fals / ne for to be traytour
(base) To me / that am thy cosyn and thy brother
(base) Ysworn ful depe / and ech of vs til oother
(base) That neuere / for to dyen in the peyne
(base) Til that the deeth / departe shal vs tweyne
(base) Neither of vs / in loue to hyndre oother
(base) Ne in noon oother caas / my leeue brother
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But that thow sholdest trewely forthre me
(base) In euery caas / as I shal forthren thee
(base) This was thyn ooth / and myn also certeyn
(base) I woot right wel / thow darst it nat withseyn
(base) Thus artow of my conseil / out of doute
(base) And now / thow woldest falsly been aboute
(base) To loue my lady / whom I loue and serue
(base) And euere shal / til that myn herte sterue
(base) Now certes false Arcite / thow shalt nat so
(base) I loued hire first and tolde thee my wo
(base) As to my conseil / and my brother sworn
(base) To forthre me / as I haue told biforn
(base) For which / thow art ybounden / as a knyght
(base) To helpe me / if it laye in thy myght
(base) Or ellis artow fals / I dar wel sayn
(base) This Arcite / ful proudly spak agayn
(base) ¶ Thow shalt quod he / be rather fals than I
(base) And thow art fals / I telle thee outrely
(base) For paramour / I loued hire first er thow
(base) What wiltow seyn / thow woost nat yet now
(base) Wheither she be a womman / or goddesse
(base) Thyn is / affeccioun of holynesse
(base) And myn is loue / as to a creature
(base) For which / I tolde thee myn auenture
(base) As to my cosyn / and my brother sworn
(base) I pose / that thow louedest hire biforn
(base) Wostow nat wel / the olde clerkes sawe
(base) That who shal / yeue a louere any lawe
(base) Quis / legem det amantibz
(base) Loue is a gretter lawe / by my pan
(base) Than may be yeue / to any erthely man
(base) And therfore / posityf lawe / and swich decree
(base) Is broke alday for loue / in ech degree
(base) A man moot nedes loue / maugree his heed
(base) He may nat fleen it / thogh he sholde be deed
(base) Al be she mayde / wydwe / or ellis wyf
(base) And eek it is nat likly / al thy lyf
(base) To stonden in hir grace / namoore shal I
(base) For wel thow woost thy self verraily
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That thow and I / been dampned to prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / vs gayneth no raunsoun
(base) We stryue / as dide the houndes / for the boon
(base) They foghte alday / and yet hir part was noon
(base) Ther cam a kyte / whil that they were so wrothe
(base) That bar awey the boon / bitwix hem bothe
(base) And therfore / at the kynges court my brother
(base) Ech man for hymself / ther is noon oother
(base) Loue if thee lest . for I loue / and ay shal
(base) And soothly / leue brother this is al
(base) Heere in this prisoun / moote we endure
(base) And euerich of vs / take his auenture
(base) ¶ Greet was the stryf / and long bitwix hem tweye
(base) If that I hadde leyser for to seye
(base) But to theffect it happed on a day
(base) To telle it yow / as shortly as I may
(base) A worthy duc . that highte Parotheus
(base) That felawe was / vnto Duc Theseus
(base) Syn thilke day / that they were children lyte
(base) Was come to Atthenes / his felawe to visite
(base) And for to pleye / as he was wont to do
(base) For in this world / he loued no man so
(base) And he loued hym / as tendrely agayn
(base) So wel they loued / as olde bookes sayn
(base) That whan that oon was deed / soothly to telle
(base) His felawe wente / and soghte hym down in helle
(base) But of that storie / list me noght to write
(base) Duc Parotheus / loued wel Arcite
(base) And hadde hym knowe at Thebes / yeer by yere
(base) And finally / at requeste and prayere
(base) Of Parotheus / withouten any raunsoun
(base) Duc Theseus / hym leet out of prisoun
(base) Frely to goon / wher that hym liste oueral
(base) In swich a gyse / as I yow tellen shal
(base) This was the forward / pleynly for tendite
(base) Bitwixe Theseus / and hym Arcite
(base) That if so weere that Arcite weere yfounde
(base) Euere in his lyf by day / or nyght or stounde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) In any contree / of this Theseus
(base) And he weere caught . it was acorded thus
(base) That with a swerd / he sholde lese his heed
(base) Ther nas noon oother / remedye ne reed
(base) But taketh his leue / and homward he hym spedde
(base) Lat hym be war / his nekke lyth to wedde
(base) Hit were a gret thing to telle and to wite
(base) ¶ How greet a sorwe / suffreth now Arcite
(base) The deeth he feeleth / thurgh his herte smyte
(base) He wepeth / wayleth / cryeth pitously
(base) To sleen hymself he wayteth pryuely
(base) He seyde allas / the day that I was born
(base) Now is my prisoun / worse than biforn
(base) Now is me shape / eternally to dwelle
(base) Noght in purgatorie / but in helle
(base) Allas / that euere knew I Parotheus
(base) For ellis / hadde I dwelled with Theseus
(base) Yfettred in his prisoun eueremo
(base) Thanne hadde I been in blisse / and nat in wo
(base) Oonly the sighte of hire / whom that I serue
(base) Thogh that I neuere / hir grace may disserue
(base) Wolde haue suffised / right ynogh for me
(base) ¶ O deere cosyn / Palamon / quod he
(base) Thyn is the victorie / of this auenture
(base) Ful blisfully / in prisoun maystow dure
(base) In prison ; / nay certes / but in paradys
(base) Wel hath Fortune / yturned thee / the dys
(base) That hast the sighte of hire / and I thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thow hast hire presence
(base) And art a knyght a worthy and an able
(base) That by som caas / syn Fortune is chaungeable
(base) Thow mayst to thy desir / som tyme atteyne
(base) But I / that am exiled and bareyne
(base) Of alle grace / and in so greet despeyr
(base) That ther nys Erthe / water / fyr / ne Eyr
(base) Ne creature / that of hem maked is
(base) That may me helpe / or do confort in this
(base) Wel oghte I sterue / in wanhope / and distresse
(base) Farwel my lyf / my lust and my gladnesse
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Allas / why pleynen folk so / in cōmmune
(base) On purueiance of god / or of Fortune
(base) That yeueth hem ful ofte / in many a gyse
(base) Wel bettre / than they kan hem self deuyse
(base) ¶ Som man desireth / for to haue richesse
(base) That cause is ofte / of his moerdre / or gret siknesse
(base) And som man wolde / out of his prison fayn
(base) That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
(base) Infinite harmes / been in this matere
(base) We woot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
(base) We fare as he / that dronke is as a Mous
(base) A dronke man woot wel / he hath an hous
(base) But he noot which the righte wey is thider
(base) And to a dronke man / . the wey is slider
(base) And certes / in this world / so faren we
(base) We seken faste / after felicitee
(base) But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
(base) Thus may we seyn alle / and nameliche I
(base) That wende / and hadde a greet opinioun
(base) That if I myghte / scapen fro prisoun
(base) Thanne hadde I been in ioye / and parfit heele
(base) Ther now / I am exiled fro my wele
(base) Syn that / I may nat seen yow Emelie
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys no remedie
(base) ¶ Vpon that oother syde Palamon
(base) Whan that he wiste / Arcite was agon
(base) Swich sorwe he maketh / that the grete tour
(base) Resowneth / of his yowlyng and clamour
(base) The pure fettres / of his shynes grete
(base) Were / of his bittre salte teeris wete
(base) Allas quod he / Arcita cosyn myn
(base) Of al oure stryf / god woot the fruyt is thyn
(base) Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
(base) And of my wo / thow yeuest litel charge
(base) Thow mayst syn thou hast wisdom / and manhede
(base) Assemblen / al the folk of oure kynrede
(base) And make a werre / so sharp / on this Citee
(base) That by som auenture / or som tretee

div.l: (base) Thow mayst haue hire / to lady and to wyf
(base) For whom / that I moste nedes lese my lyf
(base) For as by wey / of possibilitee
(base) Sith thow art at thy large / of prisoun free
(base) And art a lord / greet is thyn auantage
(base) Moore than is myn / that sterue here in a cage
(base) For I moot wepe / and waille whil I lyue
(base) With al the wo / that prison may me yeue
(base) And eek wtith peyne / that loue me yeueth also

(base) With Inne his brest and hente hym by the herte

(base) The Boxtree / or the Asshen dede / and colde
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he / o crewel goddes / that gouerne
(base) This world / with byndyng of youre word eterne
(base) And writen / in the table of Atthamaūnt
(base) Youre parlement . and youre eterne graūnt
(base) What is man kynde / moore vnto yow holde

(base) And hath siknesse / and greet aduersitee
(base) And ofte tymes / giltlees pardee
(base) ¶ What gouernance / is in this prescience
(base) That giltlees / tormenteth Innocence
(base) And yet encreeceth this / al my penance

(base) Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille

(base) Thogh in this world / he haue care and wo

(base) But wel I woot that in this world / greet pyne is

div.l: (base) Goon at his large / and where hym lust may turne

(base) And Venus / sleeth me / on that oother syde

(base) ¶ The Somer / and the nyghtes longe

(base) Who hath the worse / Arcite / or Palamoun

(base) That oother / where hym list may ride or go
(base) But seen his lady / shal he neuere mo

(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / to Thebes comen was

(base) So muchel sorwe / hadde neuere creature
(base) That is or shal / whil that the world may dure
(base) ¶ His sleep / his mete / his drynke / is hym biraft

div.l: (base) That falleth nat eft / with Inne a thousand yeer

(base) Al is this ruled / by the sighte aboue
(base) ¶ This mene I now / by myghty Theseus
(base) That for to hunten / is so desirus
(base) And namely / at the grete hert in May

(base) ¶ Cleer was the day / as I haue told er this

(base) Vnder the sonne he looketh / and anon

(base) That foghten breme / as it were boles two

div.l: (base) Namoore / vpon peyne / of lesyng of youre heed

(base) That been so hardy / for to fighten heer
(base) Withouten Iuge / or oother officer
(base) As it weere in a lystes roially
(base) ¶ This Palamon / answerde hastily
(base) And seyde / sire / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And seide sire what nedith wordes moo
(base) We haue the deeth disserued / bothe two

(base) Ne yif vs / neither mercy ne refuge

(base) This is thy mortal foo / this is Arcite

(base) And this is he / that loueth Emelye
(base) For sith the day is come / that I shal dye
(base) I make pleynly / my confessioun
(base) That I am / thilke woful Palamoun

(base) I am thy mortal foo / and it am I

(base) For bothe haue we / deserued to be slayn
(base) ¶ This worthy Duc answerde anoon agayn
(base) And seyde / this is a short conclusioun
(base) Youre owene mouth / by youre confessioun

div.l: (base) Hath dampned yow / and I wol it recorde
(base) It nedeth noght to pyne yow with the corde
(base) Ye shul be deed / by myghty Mars the rede
(base) ¶ The queene anoon / for verray wommanhede
(base) Gan for to wepe / and so dide Emelye
(base) And alle the ladies / in the compaignye
(base) Greet pitee was it / as it thoughte hem alle
(base) That euere swich a chaunce / sholde falle
(base) For gentil men they weere / of greet estaat
(base) And no thyng but for loue / was this debaat
(base) And sawe / hir blody wowndes / wide and soore
(base) And alle cryden / bothe lasse and moore
(base) Haue mercy lord / vpon vs wommen alle
(base) And on hir bare knees / adown they falle

(base) Til at the laste / aslaked was his mood

(base) And thogh he first. for Ire quook and sterte

(base) ¶ As thus / he thoghte wel that euery man
(base) Wol helpe hymself in loue / if that he kan

(base) And eek his herte hadde compassioun
(base) Of wommen / for they wepten euere in oon
(base) And in his gentil herte / he thoghte anoon

(base) Vpon a lord / that wol haue no mercy
(base) But be a leoun bothe in word and dede
(base) To hem / that been in repentaunce and drede
(base) As wel / as to a proud despitous man
(base) That wol mayntene / that he first bigan
(base) That lord / hath litel of discrecioun
(base) That in swich caas / kan no dyuysioun
(base) But weyeth pryde / and humblesse / after oon
(base) And shortly / whan his Ire is thus agoon

div.l: (base) He gan to loken vp / with eyen lighte

(base) ¶ The god of loue / a benedicitee
(base) How myghty / and how greet a lord is he
(base) Agayns his myght . ther gayneth none obstacles
(base) He may be clepid a god / for his miracles
(base) For he kan maken / at his owene gyse
(base) Of euerich herte / as that hym list deuyse
(base) ¶ Lo here / this Arcite / and this Palamoun
(base) That quitly were / out of my prisoun
(base) And myghte haue lyued in Thebes roially
(base) And witen / I am hir mortal enemy

(base) Broght hem hyder / bothe for to dye
(base) Now looketh / is nat that an heigh folye
(base) ¶ Who may been a fool / but if he loue
(base) Bihoold for goddes sake / that sit aboue
(base) Se how they blede / be they noght wel arrayed
(base) Thus hath hir lord / the god of loue ypayed

(base) But this is yet the beste game of alle
(base) That she / for whom / they haue this Iolitee

(base) By god / than woot a cokkow of an hare
(base) But al moot been assayed / hoot and coold
(base) A man moot been a fool / or yong or oold
(base) I woot it by myself / ful yoore agoon

(base) And therfore / syn I knowe of loues peyne
(base) And woot how soore / it kan a man distreyne

(base) I yow foryeue / al hoolly this trespas
(base) At requeste of the queene / that kneeleth heere
(base) And eek of Emelye / my suster deere

div.l: (base) And ye shal bothe anoon / vnto me swere

(base) I yow foryeue / this trespas euerydel

(base) ¶ To speke of roial lynage / and richesse
(base) Thogh that she weere a queene / or a princesse
(base) Ech of yow bothe / is worthy doutelees
(base) To wedden whan tyme is / but nathelees
(base) I speke / as for my suster Emelye

(base) Atones / thogh ye fighten eueremo

(base) Withouten any replicacioun

(base) And this bihoote I yow / withouten faille
(base) Vpon my trouthe / and as I am a knyght
(base) That wheither of yow bothe / that hath myght

div.l: (base) Sleen his contrarie / or out of lystes dryue

div.l: (base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun

(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus

div.l: (base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet

(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see

(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked

(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught

(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo

(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet

(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown

(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn

div.l: (base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name

(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe

div.l: (base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel

(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed

(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge

(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars

div.l: (base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste

div.l: (base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee

div.l: (base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances
(base) Al telle I nat as now / his obseruances
(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook
(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
(base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye

div.l: (base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan

div.l: (base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon
(base) As it were / blody dropes many oon
(base) For which / so soore agast was Emelye
(base) That she was wel neigh mad / and gan to crye
(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
(base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed
(base) And by eterne word / writen and confermed

div.l: (base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf
(base) And moore encens / in to the fyr he caste
(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie
(base) For which / he yaf to Mars / honour and glorie
(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare
(base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
(base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art

(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles

div.l: (base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
(base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
(base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day
(base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce
(base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
(base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
(base) Ther was in hostelryes / al aboute
(base) And to the paleys / rood ther many a route
(base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
(base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers

div.l: (base) Nailynge the speres / and the helmes bokelynge
(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
(base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also
(base) With fyle and hamer / prykyng to and fro
(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon
(base) With shorte staues / thikke as they may goon
(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down
(base) Heer thre / ther ten / holdynge hir questioun
(base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two
(base) Somme seyde thus / somme seyden it shal be so
(base) Somme helden with hym / with the blake berd
(base) Somme with the balled / somme with the thikke herd
(base) Somme seyde / he looked grym / and he wolde fighte
(base) He hath a Sparth / of twenty pound of wighte
(base) Thus was the halle / ful of deuynynge
(base) Longe after / that the sonne gan to sprynge
(base) ¶ The grete Theseus / that of his sleep awaked
(base) With mynstralcye / and noyse that was maked
(base) Held yet the chambres / of his paleys ryche
(base) Til that the Theban knyghtes / bothe yliche
(base) Honoured /. weren in to the Paleys fet
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / is at a wyndow set
(base) Arrayed / right as he weere a god in Trone
(base) The peple preeseth / thiderward ful soone

(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
(base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon

div.l: (base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence

div.l: (base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue

div.l: (base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
(base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght

div.l: (base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
And here by gynneth þe ꝓprolog / of þe Millere
Whan þat þe knight had þus his tale told
In all the company nas þꝰere ȝong ne old
That he ne seide it was anoble storie
And worthi to be drawe in memorie
And nameliche þe gentiles euꝰerichon
Oure oost lowh ⁊ swore so mote I gon
Was torned forto lerne Astrologie
And coude a certeyn of conclusioūns
To demen by Interrogacioūns
Ȝif þat men axed him in certeyn houres
Whan þat men scholde haue droght or schoures
Or ȝif men axid him what schulde befalle
Of euery þing I may not rekene alle
This clerk was cleped hend Nicholas
Of derne loue he couthe ⁊ prive solas
And þꝰerto he was slyh ⁊ ful pryue
And like to a maide meke forto see
A chambre hadde he in þat hostelrie
Alone wiþ oute any companye
Ful fetisly dight with herbes soote
And he him self as swete as is the roote
Of licorice or any situale
His almagist ⁊ bookes grete ⁊ smale
His asterlabre longing for his art
His augrym stones laien ful faire a part
On schelues couched at his beddes heed
His presse I couꝰered with a faldyng reed
And all aboue þere lay agay sawtrie
On whiche he made on nyght melodie
So sweteli þat al the chambre rong
And angelus ad virginem he song
And after þat he song the kynges note
Ful ofte blessid was his mery throte
And þus the swete clerk his tyme spent
After his frendes fynding and his rent
This carpenter had weddid anewe wyf
Whiche þat he loued more þan his lyf
Of xviij ȝere sche was of aage
Ielous he was and kept hir streight in caage
For sche was wilde ⁊ ȝong ⁊ he was old
And demed him self to be like a Cokewold
He knew not Catoūn for his wit was rude
Þat bad men schulde wedde his similitude
Men schulde wedde after here estate
For ȝouthe ⁊ elde is often at debate
But sithen he was fallen in the snare
He moste endure as other folk his care
Faire was this ȝonge wyf ⁊ þerewith al
As any wesil hir body gent ⁊ smal
A seynt sche wered barred al of silk
A barme cloth as white as morwen mylk
Vpon hir lendes ful of many a gore
White was hir smok ⁊ browded al bifore
And eek be hynde on hir coler a boute
Of col blak silk with ynne ⁊ eke with oute
The tapes of her white volipere
Were of þe same sute of hir colere
Hire filet brood of silk ⁊ sette ful hie
And sikerly sche hadde a likerous yghe
Ful smal I pulled were hir browes two
And tho were bent ⁊ blak as eny slo
Sche was ful more blisful forto see
Thenne is þe newe ꝑperienet tree
And softer þan the wolle is of a wethir
And by hir girdel heng a purs of lethir
Tassid with silk ⁊ perled with latoūn
In all this world to seken vp ⁊ doūn
Ther nys no man so wise þat couthe þenche
So gay a popelote or suche a wenche
Ful brighter was þe schynyng of hir hiewe
Than in the tour þe noble forged newe
But of hir song it was as lowde ⁊ ȝerne
As any swalue sittynge on a berne
Therto sche couthe skippe ⁊ make a game
As any kyde or calf folowyng his dame
Hir mouth was swete as bragot or þe meth
Or hord of apples leid in hey or heth
Wynsing sche was as is a ioly colt
Longe as a mast ⁊ vpright as a bolt
A broche sche bare on hir loue coler
As brood as is the boos of a bokeler
Her schoos were laced on her legges hie
Sche was aprimerole a pigges nyhe
For any lord to liggen in his bed
Or ȝet for any yeman to wed
Now sire and eft sire ⁊ so bifel the cas
That on a day this hende Nicholas
Gan with þis ȝonge wyf to rage ⁊ to play
While þat hire housbonde was at Osenay
As clerkes ben ful subtil ⁊ ful queynte
And pryuely he caught hire by the queynte
And saide I wis but I haue my wille
For derne loue of the leman I spille
And held hir faste by þe haūnche bones
And seide lēmman loue me wel at ones
Or I wil dye as god me saue
And sche sprong as colt doth in the traue
And with hir heed sche wried faste away
Sche seide I wil not kesse the be my fay
Whi lat be quod iche late be Nicholas
Or I wil crie out harrow ⁊ alas
Do way ȝoure hondes for ȝoure Curtesie
This Nicholas gan mercy forto crie
And spak so faire ⁊ profred him so faste
That sche hir loue graūnted him atte laste
And swoor hire oth by seint Thomas of kent
That sche wolde be at his comaūndement
Whan þat sche may her leyser wel aspye
Myn housbonde is so ful of Ielousie
That but ȝe waite wel ⁊ ben pryue
I wote right wel I nam but deed quod sche
Ȝe mote ben ful derne as in this cas
Nay þere of care ȝe not quod Nicholas
A clerk hadde litherly bisette his while
But ȝif he coude a carpenter be gile
And þus thei are acorded ⁊ sworne
To wayte a tyme as I haue seide biforne
Whan Nicholas had don þus euꝰeridel
And thakkid hire aboute the lendes wel
He kisseth hir swete ⁊ taketh his sawtrie
And plaieth faste ⁊ maketh melodie
Than fil hit thus þat to the parisshe chirche
Cristes owne werkes forto wirche
This good wyf went vpon an holy day
Hire forheed schoon as bright as eny day
So was it wasche whan sche lete her werk
Now was ther of þe chirche a parische clerk
The whiche þat was cleped Absolon
Crull was his heed and as þe gold it schoon
And strouted as a vanne large ⁊ brood
Ful streyte ⁊ euene lay his Ioly schood
His rode was reed his eien gray as goos
With poules wyndowes corven on his schoos
In hosen rede he wente fetisly
I clad he was ful smal and ꝓpropirly
All in a kirtel of a light waget
Ful faire and þikke ben the poyntes sette
And þꝰere vpon he hadde a gay surplice
As white as is þe blosme on the ryce
A merie child he was so god me saue
Wel coude he late blood clippe ⁊ schaue
And make a chartre of lond or aquitaūnce
In twenty manꝰere coude he trippe ⁊ daūnce
After the scole of Oxenford thoo
And with his legges too ⁊ froo
And plaien songes on a smale ribible
Somtyme he song a lowde quinible
And as wel couthe he play on a giterne
In all þe toūn nas brewhous ne tauerne
Þat he ne visiteth with his solas
Ther any gailerd tapster was
But soth to sayne he was somdel squaymous
Of fartyng and of speche daūngerous
This Absolon þat was Ioly ⁊ gay
Goth with a sensere on the holiday
Sensyng the wyfes of þe parische faste
And many a louely look on hem he caste
And namely on þe Carpenters wyf
To loke on hire him þoght amery lyf
Sche was so ꝓpropre ⁊ swete ⁊ likerous
I dar wel seie and sche had be a mous
And he a Catte he wolde hir hente anon
This parische Clerke þis Ioly absolon
Hath in his herte suche a loue longing
That of no wyf took he none offering
For curtesie he seide he wolde noon
The mone whan it was nyght / bright schoon
And absolon his giterne haþ take
For ꝑperamours he þoghte forto wake
And forth he goth Ielouse ⁊ amerous
Til he come til þe Carpenters hous
A litel after þe Cok hadde I crowe
And dressed hym vnder a schot wyndowe
Þat was vpon the Carpenters wall
He syngeth in his vois gentil ⁊ small
Now dere lady ȝif thi wil be
I preie ȝow þat ȝe will rewe on me
Ful wel accordant to his giternynge
This Carpenter a wook ⁊ herde him singe
And spake vnto his wyf ⁊ seide a non
What Alison whi herest þou not Absolon
Þat chaunteth þus vnder oure boure wal
And sche answerde hir housbonde þꝰere with al
Yis god woot Iohn I here him euꝰeridel
This passeth forth what wil ȝe þan but wel
Fro day to day this Ioly Absolon
So woweth hire þat him was wo bygon
He waketh all þe nyght ⁊ all the day
He kembeth his lokkes brode ⁊ made hem gay
He woweth hire by menes ⁊ brocage
And swore he wolde ben hir owne page
He singeth brokkyng as a nyghtingale
He sent hir pyment meth ⁊ spiced ale
And wafres pipyng hoot out of the glede
And for sche was of towne he ꝓprofred mede
For some folk wil be wonnen for richesse
And some for strokes ⁊ somefor gentilnesse
Somtyme to schewe his lightnesse ⁊ maistrie
He plaieth herawdes vpon a scaffold hihe
But what availeth him as in this cas
So loueth sche þis hende Nicholas
That Absolon may blowe the bukkes horn
He ne hadde for his labour but a scorn
And þus sche maketh absolon hir Ape
And all ernest torneth to a iape
For sothe is this ꝓprouerbe it is no lye
Men seyn thus alwey the neighe slye
Maketh the fer leef to be loth
For þogh þat Absolon be wood or wrooth
By cause þat he fer was from her sight
This nyghe Nicholas stood in his light
Now bere the wel hende Nicholas
For absolon may waile ⁊ synge alas
And so bifelle hit on a satirday
This Carpunter was gone to Osenay
And hende Nicholas ⁊ alisoūn
Acorded were to this conclusioūn
That Nicholas schal schapen hem a wile
This sely Ielouse housbonde to begile
And if so be the game wente aright
Sche schulde slepe in his arme al nyght
For þis was his desire ⁊ hir also
And right anon wiþ oute wordes mo
This Nicholas no lenger wolde tarie
But doth ful softe vnto his cambre carie
Bothe mete ⁊ drink for aday or tweie
And to hir housbonde badde hir forto seie
Ȝif þat he axed after Nicholas
Sche scholde seie sche nyste where he was
Of all þat day sche say him not with yghe
Sche trowed þat he was in maladie
For for no cry hir maide coude him calle
He nolde answere for noght þat might befalle
This passeth forth al thilke satirday
That Nicholas stille in his chambre lay
And ete ⁊ sleep or dide what him leste
Til sonneday þat þe sonne goth to reste
This seli carpenter hath grete mervaile
Of Nicholas or what þing might him aile
And seide I am adrad by seint Thomas
It stondeth not aright with Nicholas
God schilde þat he deide sodenly
This world is now ful tikel sikerly
I sawh to day acorps born to chirche
That now on Monday last I sawh him wirche
Go vp quod he vnto his knaue anoon
Clepe at his dore or knokke wiþ a stoon
Loke how it is ⁊ telle me boldely
This knaue wente him vp ful sturdely
And atte chambre dore while þat he stood
He cried ⁊ knokked as þat he were wood
What how what do ȝe maister Nicholay
How may ȝe slepen all þis longe day
But all forth noght he herde neuꝰere a word
An hole he fond ful lowe vpon a bord
There as þe Catte was wont in forto crepe
And atte laste he loked in ful depe
And at þe laste he hadde of him a sight
This Nicholas satte euere Capyng vp right
As he hadde kiked on the newe mone
A doūn he goth and tolde his maister sone
In what array he sawh þis ilke man
This Carpenter to blessen him bigan
And seide helpe vs seint Frideswide
A man woot litel what him schal be tide
This man is fallen with his Astronomye
In some woodnesse or some Agonye
I þoght wel how hit scholde be
Men schulde not knowe of goddes pryuyte
Ȝe blessid be alway the lewed man
That not but only his bileue can
So ferde another Clerk with Astronomye
He walked in the feldes forto prye
Vpon þe sterres to wite what scholde bifalle
Til he was in a Marleput I falle
I sawh not þat but ȝit by senit Thomas
Me reweth sore for hynde Nicholas
He schal be ratid of his studieng
Ȝif þat I may by Ihūns heuen kyng
Gete me a staf þat I may vnderspore
While þat þou Robyn heuest vp the dore
He schal oute of his studieng as I gesse
And to the chambre dore he gan him dresse
His knaue was astronge carle for the nones
And by þe hasp he haf it vp at ones
In to þe floor the dore fel anon
This Nicholas satte ay stille as stoon
And euer Caped vpward in to þe aire
This carpenter wende he were in dispeire
And hent him by the schuldres mightily
And schoke him harde ⁊ cried spitously
What Nicholay what how loke adoūn
A wake and thenke on cristes passioūn
I crouche the from Elues ⁊ fro wightes
There with þe nyght spel he seide anon rightes
On foure halfes of the hous aboute
And on the þresshefold on þe dore wiþoute
Ihūn crist and seint Benedight
Blisse this hous from euꝰery wicked wight
For þe nightes verie þe white pater nr
Where wentestow þou seint petres suster
And atte laste þis hende Nicholas
Gan forto sike ⁊ sore seide allas
Schal all the world be lost eft sones now
This Carpenter answerde what seist þow
What þinke on god as we don men þat swynke
This Nicholas answerde fecche me drinke
And after wil I speke in pryuite
Of certein þing þat touche the ⁊ me
I wil telle hit non other man certeyn
This carpenter goth doūn ⁊ cometh a geyn
And broght of myghti ale alarge quart
And whan þat eche of hem had dronken his part
This Nicholas his dore faste schette
And doūn the Carpunter by him he sette
And seide Iohūn myn Ost lief ⁊ dere
Thow schalt vpon thi trouthe swere me here
That to no wight þou schalt þis coūnseil wreie
For hit is cristes coūnseil þat I seie
And ȝif thou telle hit man þou art for lore
For þis vengeance þou schalt haue þꝰerfore
That if thou wreie me þou schalt be wood
¶ Nay crist forbede hit for his holy blood
Quod tho þis sely man I nam no labbe
Ne þogh I seie I ne am not leef to gabbe
Sey what þou wolt I schal it neuꝰere telle
To child ne wyf by him þat harwed helle
Now Iohn qd Nicholas I wil naught lye
I haue founden in myn astrologie
As I haue loked in the mone bright
That now amonday next aquarter nyght
Schal falle areyn ⁊ þat so wylde and wood
That half so greet was neuꝰere Noes flood
This world he seide in lesse þan in an hour
Schal all be dreint so hidous is the schour
Thus schal mankynde drenche ⁊ lese her lyf
This Carperter answerde alas my wyf
And schal sche drenche allas myn Alisoūn
For sorwe of this he fel almost adoūn
And seide is there no remedie in this caas
Whi ȝis for gode qd hende Nicholas
If þou wilt worchen after lore ⁊ reed
Thou maist not werken after thyn owne heed
For þus seith salamon þat was ful trewe
Work all by coūnseil and þou schalt not rewe
And ȝif þou werken wilt by good coūnsaile
I vndertake with oute mast or saile
Yet schal I saue hire ⁊ the and me
Hastow not herd how saued was Noe
Whan þat oure lord haþ warned him biforn
That all þe world wiþ water schal be lorn
Ȝis qd þis Carpenter ful ȝore agoo
Hast þou not herd quod Nicholas also
The sorwe of Noe with his felawschipe
Or þat he mighte gete his wyf to schipe
Him hadde leuere I dar wel vndertake
At þilke tyme þan all his wethris blake
That sche hadde a schip hir self allone
And þꝰerfore wost þou what is best to done
This axeth haste ⁊ of an hastyf thing
Men may nought preche or make tarienge
Anon go gete vs faste in to þis Inne
A knedyng trough or elles a kemelyn
For eche of vs but loke þat þei ben large
In whiche men mowen swyme as in a barge
And han þere vitailes suffisant
But for a day fy on the remenant
The water schal aslake and gon away
A boute prime vpon the nexte day
But Robyn may not wite of this thi knaue
Ne eke þi maide gille I may not saue
Axe noght whi for þogh þou axe me
I wol not tellen goddes pryuete
Sufficeþ the but ȝif thi wittes madde
To haue as faire a grace as Noe hadde
Thi wyf schal I wel sauen out of doute
Go now thi wey ⁊ spede the here aboute
But whan þou hast for hire ⁊ the ⁊ me
I geten vp thise knedinge tubbes thre
Than schalt þou hange hem in þe roof ful hye
That no man of oure purveaūnce espie
And whan þou þus hast don as I haue seide
And hast oure vitaile faire in hem leide /
And eke an axe to smyte the corde a two
Whan þat þe water cometh þat we may go
And broke an hole on hie vpon the gable
Vnto the gardynward ouer the stable
That we may frely passen forth oure wey
When þat the grete schoure is goon a wey
Thanne schalt þou swyme as merie I vndertake
As doth þe white doke after his drake
Than wole I clepe how alisoūn how Iohn
Be merie for the blood wil passe anon
And þou wolt seyn heile maister Nicholay
Gode morwen I see the wel for hit is day
And þan schal we be lordes al oure lyf
Of all the world as Noe and his wyf
But þat of oo thing I warne þe ful right
Be wel avised on þat ilke nyght
That we ben entred into schippes bord
That none of vs ne speke noght aword
Ne clepe ne crie but be in his prayere
For it is goddes owne heste dere
Thy wyf and þou mote hange fer atwynne
For þat bitwene ȝow schal be no synne
Na more in lokynge þan þꝰere schal in dede
This ordinaūnce is seide go god the spede
To morwe at nyght whan men ben alle on slepe
In to oure knedinge tubbes wil we crepe
And sitten there abidyng goddes grace
Go now thi wey I haue no lenger space
To make of this no lenger sermonyng
Men seyn thus sende the wise ⁊ seie no thing
Thow art so wys it nedeth þe not to teche
Go saaf oure lyf ⁊ þat I the biseche
¶ This sely carpunter goth forth his weie
Ful ofte he seide alas and weilaweie
And to his wyf he tolde his pryuete
And sche was war ⁊ knewe hit bet þan he
What all þis queynte caste was forto seie
But natheles sche ferde as sche wolde deie
And seide allas goo forth þi wey anon
Helpe vs to scape and we ben deed echon
I am thi trewe vꝰerray wedded wyf
Go dere spouse and helpe to saue oure lyf
Lo whiche agrete thing is affeccioūn
Men may deie of ymaginacioūn
So depe may impressioūn be take
This sely Carpenter bygynneth to quake
Him þinketh vꝰerrayliche þat he may see
Noes flood come walkynge as the see
To drenchen alisoūn his hony dere
He wepeth waileth maketh sory chere
He siketh with ful many a sory swough
And goth ⁊ getith him a knedyng trough
And after þat a tubbe and a kemelyn
And pryuely he sent hem to his yn
And heng hem in þe roof in piriuete
His owne hand made eke laddres thre
To clymben by þe ronges ⁊ þe stalkes
Vnto þe tubbes hangyng in þe balkes
And hem vitailled bothe trough ⁊ tuble
With brede and chese ⁊ good ale in a Iubbe
Suffising right I now as for a day
But ar þat he hadde all this array
He sente his knaue ⁊ eke his wenche also
Vpon his nede to londoūn forto goo
And on the monday whan it drough to night
He schette his dore with oute Candel light
Andressith all þing as it scholde be
And schortly clumben vp all thre
Thei seten stille well a forlong way
Now Pater noster Clum seide Nicholay
And Clum qd Iohn and clum seide alisoūn
This carpunter seide his deuocioūn
And stille he sitte ⁊ biddeþ his prayere
A waityng on the rayn if he it here
The dede sleep for wery besinesse
Fil on this carpenter right as I gesse
A boute Corfew tyme or litel more
For trauaile of his goost he groneth sore
And efte he routeth for his heed mislay
Doun of the laddre stalketh Nicholay
And alisoūn ful softe a doūn sche spedde
With outen wordes mo thei gon to bedde
Ther as the Carpunter is wont to lye
Ther was the Reuel and the melodie
And þus lieth Alisoūn and Nicholas
In besynesse of merthe ⁊ of solas
Til þat the belle of laudes gan to rynge
And freres in the chaūncel gan synge
¶ This parische clerk this amerous absolon
That is for loue alwey so woo by goon
Vpon the monday was at Osenay
With compaignie him to desport ⁊ play
And axed vpon cas a cloistrer
Ful piriuely after Iohn the Carpunter
And he drowh him apart out of the chirche
And seide I not I say him here not wirche
Sith satirday I trowe þat he be went
For tymber there oure Abbot haþ him sent
For he is wont for tymber forto goo
And dwellen at a graūnge a day or two
Or elles he is at his hous certeyn
Where þat he be I can noght sothely seyn
This Absolon ful ioly was ⁊ light
And þoghte now is tyme to wake all nyght
For sikerly I saw him noght stiryng
A bouten his dore syn day bigan to spryng
So mote I thryue I schall atte cokkes crowe
Ful priuely knokken at his wyndowe
That stant ful lowe vpon his bowres wall
To Alisoūn now will I tellen all
Mi loue longing For ȝit I schal not mysse
That atte leste wey I schal hir kisse
Som manꝰere comfort schal I haue parfay
Mi mouth hath icched all þis longe day
That is a signe of kissyng atte leste
Al nyght me mette eke I was at a feste
Therfore I wil goo slepe an houre or tweie
And all the nyght þan wole I wake ⁊ pleie
Whan þat the firste Cok haþ crowe anon
Vp rist this Ioly louer Absolon
And him arrayeth gay ⁊ point devise
But firste he cheweth greyn ⁊ likorise
To smellen swote whan he had kēmpt his here
Vnder his tonge atrewe loue he bere
For þer by wende he to be gracious
He rometh to þe Carpenters hous
And stille he stant vnder þe schot wyndowe
Vnto his brest it raught it was so lowe
And softe he coughed wiþ a semy sown
What do ȝe hony comb swete Alisoūn
My faire brid my swete synamome
A waketh lēmman myn ⁊ speketh to me
Wel litel þinken ȝe vpon my woo
That for ȝoure loue I swete as I goo
No wonder is þogh þat I swelte ⁊ swete
I moorne as doth þe lamb after the tete
I wis lēmman I haue suche loue longing
That like a turtel trewe is my mornyng
I may not eten na more þan a maide
Go fro the wyndow Iakke fool sche saide
As helpe me god it wil not be compame
I loue an other and elles I were to blame
Wel bet þan the by Ihūn Absolon
Go forth þi wey or I will caste astoon
And lete me slepe atwenty deuel way
Allas quod Absolon and weilaway
That trewe loue was euer so evil bysette
Than kysse me syn it may be no bette
For ihus loue ⁊ for the loue of me
Wilt þou thanne go thi way þꝰerwith qd sche
Ye certes lēmman quod þis Absolon
Than make the redy quod sche I come anon
This Absolon doūn sette him on his knees
And seide I am alord at all degrees
For after this I hope þere cometh more
Lēmman thi grace and swete brid thyn ore
The wyndow sche vndoth and þat in haste
Haue do quod sche come of ⁊ spede the faste
Lest þat oure neigheboures the espie
This absolon gan wipe his mouth ful drie
Derk was the night as picche or as þe cole
And out at þe wyndow sche putte hire ers hole
And Absolon him fel noþer better ne wers
But wiþ his mouth he kessid hire naked ers
Ful sauourly or he was war of this
A bak he sterte ⁊ þoghte it was a mys
For wel he wiste a wōmman haþ no berd
He felte athing al rough and longe I hered
And seide fy allas what haue I doo
Tehe quod sche ⁊ clapt the wyndow to
And Absolon goth forth a sory paas
Aberde aberde seide hende Nicholas
By goddes corpus this goth faire ⁊ well
This sely absolon herde it euꝰery dell
And on his lippe he gan for anger bite
And to him self he seide I schal the quite
Who rubbeth now who froteth now his lippes
With dust with sond with straw with cloþ wiþ chippes
But Absolon þat seith ful ofte Allas
My soule bitake I to sathanas
But me were leuere þan all this toūn quod he
Of this despite a wroken forto be
Allas quod he allas I ne hadde y bleynt
His hote loue is cold ⁊ all I queynt
For fro þat tyme þat he hadde kest hire ers
Of ꝑperamours he sette noght akers
For he was heled of his maladie
Ful ofte ꝑperamoures he gan diffie
And wepte as doth a child þat is I bete
A softe paas he wente ouer þe strete
Vntill a smyth men clepen daun Gerveis
That in his forge smythieþ plowh harneys
He scharpeth sharre and culter besily
This Absolon knokketh all esily
And seide vndo Gerueys ⁊ þat anon
What who art þow . It am I absolon
What Absolon for cristes swete tree
Why rise ȝe so rathe ey benedicite
What eileth ȝow som gay gerle god it woot
Haþ broght ȝow þus on the veritoot
By seynte note ȝe wote wel what I mene
This Absolon ne roghte not a bene
Of all his pleye no word ageyn he gaf
He hadde more tough on his distaf
Than gerveys knewe ⁊ seide frend so dere
The hote Culter in the chemeney here
As lene it me I haue þꝰerwith to done
I wol bringe hit aȝeyn ful soone
Gerveis answerde certes were it gold
Or in a poke nobles all vntold
Thou schuldest it haue as I am trewe smyth
Ey cristes foo what wil ȝe doo þerwith
Therof quod Absolon be as be may
I schal well tellen hit the to morwe day
And caughte the culter by the colde stele
Ful softe oute atte dore he gan to stele
And wente vnto the Carpenters wall
He kowhede first ⁊ knokked þꝰere with all
Vpon the wyndow right as he dide ere
This Alisoūn answerde who is there
That knokketh so I warente it a theef
Why nay quod he god woot my swete leef
I am thyn Absolon thi derlyng
Of gold quod he I haue the broght a ryng
My moder ȝaf it me so god me saue
Ful fyn it is and þꝰerto wel I graue
This wil I ȝeuen the if þou me kysse
This Nicholas was risen forto pisse
And þoghte he wolde amenden al þe Iape
He scholde kisse his ers er þat he skape
And vp the wyndow dide he hastifly
And out his ers he putte priuely
Over the buttok to the haunche boon
And þꝰerwith spak this clerk this Absolon
Speke swete brid I not where þou art
This Nicholas anoon leet flee a fart
As grete as it hadde be athonder dent
That with þe strook he was almost I blent
And he was redy with his Iren hoot
And Nicholas in the ers he smoot
Of goth þe skyn an handebrede aboute
The hote culter brenned so his toute
¶ And for þe smert he wende forto deie
As he were wood for woo he gan to crie
Help water water help for goddes herte
This Carpunter out of his slumber sterte
And herde oon crien water as he were wood
And þoghte allas now cometh Noes flood
And sette him vp with oute wordes mo
And with an ax he smoot the corde a two
And doūn goth al he fond neither to selle
No breed nor ale til he com to the selle
Vppon þe floor and þꝰere adoūn he lay
Vp stirte hire Alisoūn and Nicholay
And cried out and harrow in þe strete
The neighebores bothe smale ⁊ grete
In ronnen forto gauren on this man
That aswowne lay bothe pale ⁊ wan
For with þat fall he brosten haþ his arme
But stonden he moste vnto his owne harme
For whan he spak he was anon bore doūn
With hende Nicholas and Alisoūn
Thei tolde euꝰeryman þat he was wood
He was agast so of Nowels flood
Thurgh fantasie þat of his vanite
He hadde I boght him knedynge tubbes thre
And hadde hem hanged in the roof a boue
And þat he preied him for goddes loue
To sitten in the roof ꝑper companye
The Folk gan lawhen at his fantasie
And to the roof þei kiken and thei cape
And turned all his arme vnto a iape
For what so this Carpenter answerde
It was for noght no man his resoūn herde
He was anon right boren doūn
That he was holden wood in all þe toūn
For euꝰery clerk anon right helde with oþer
The seide the man is wood my leue brother
And euꝰery wight gan lawhen at þis stryf
Thus swyued was the Carpunters wyf
For al his kepyng and his Ialousie
And Absolon hath kessid hir nether eyghe
And Nicholas is scalded in his toute
This tale is doon and god saue all the route
here endith the Millers tale

(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas

(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
