div.l: (base) A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
(base) On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
(base) With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
(base) And she cam after in a gyte of reed
(base) And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
(base) Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
(base) Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
(base) That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
(base) But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
(base) With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
(base) For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
(base) Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
(base) And eek for she was som del smoterlich
(base) She was as digne as water in a dich
(base) And ful of hoker and of bismare
(base) Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
(base) What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
(base) That she hadde lerned in the Nonnerye
(base) A doghter hadde they bitwix hem two
(base) Of twenty yeer with outen any mo
(base) Sauyng a child that was of hal yeer age
(base) In Cradel it lay and was a propre page
(base) This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was
(base) With camuse nose and eyen greye as glas
(base) With buttokes brode and brestes rounde and hye
(base) But right fair was hir heer I wol nat lye
(base) The person of the toun for she was so feir
(base) In purpos was to maken hir his heir

(base) And straunge he made it of hir mariage

(base) His purpos was for to bistowe hir hye
(base) In to som worthy blood of Auncetrye
(base) For holicherches good moot been despended
(base) On holicherches blood that is descended

div.l: (base) And nameliche ther was a greet Collegge
(base) Men clepeth the soler halle at Cantebregge
(base) Ther was hir whete and eek hir malt ygrounde
(base) And on a day it happed in a stounde
(base) Syk was this maunciple on a maladie
(base) Men wenden wisly that he sholde dye
(base) For which this Millere stal bothe mele and corn
(base) An hondred tyme moore than biforn

(base) But now he was a theef outrageously
(base) For which the wardeyn chidde and made fare

(base) Thanne were ther yonge poure scolers two

div.l: (base) Hym bihoues serue hym self that has na swayn
(base) Or ellis he is a fool as clerkes sayn
(base) Oure maunciple I hope he wol be deed

(base) And ther fore is I come and eek Alayn
(base) To grynde oure corn and carie it heem agayn
(base) I pray yow speed vs heythen what ye may
(base) It shal be doon quod Symkyn by my fay

(base) Quod Iohn and se how the corn gas In

(base) How that the hoper wagges til and fra

(base) I is as ille a Millere as ar ye
(base) This Millere smyled of hir nycetee
(base) And thoghte al this nys doon but for a wyle
(base) They wene that no man may hem bigile

(base) The moore queynte crekys that they make

div.l: (base) This Millere gooth ayein no word he seyde

(base) And whan the mele was sakked and ybounde
(base) This Iohn gooth out and fynt his hors away

(base) Oure hors is lost. Alayn for goddes banes

(base) This Alayn al forgat bothe mele and corn

(base) Allas quod Iohn Aleyn for Cristes peyne

(base) I is ful wight god waat as is a ra

(base) But he that noght hath ne coueiteth haue
(base) Is riche althogh we holde hym but a knaue
(base) Verray pouerte is synne proprely
(base) Iuuenal seith of pouerte myrily
(base) The poure man whan he gooth by the weye
(base) Biforn the theues he may synge and pleye
(base) Pouerte is hateful good and as I gesse
(base) A ful greet bryngere out of bisynesse
(base) A greet amendere eek of Sapience
(base) To hym that taketh it in pacience
(base) Pouerte is thyng althogh it seme elenge
(base) Possessioun that no wight wol chalenge
(base) Pouerte ful often whan a man is lowe
(base) Maketh hymself and eek his god to knowe
(base) Pouerte a spectacle is as thynketh me
(base) Thurgh which he may his verray freendes se
(base) And therfore sire syn that I noght yow greue
(base) Of my pouerte namoore ye me repreue
(base) Now sire of elde ye repreue me
(base) And certes sire thogh noon auctoritee
(base) Were in no book ye gentils of honour
(base) Seyn that men an old wight sholde doon fauour
(base) And clepe hym fader for youre gentilesse
(base) And Auctours shal I fynden as I gesse
(base) Now ther ye seye that I am foul and old
(base) Thanne drede yow noght to been a Cokewold
(base) For filthe and elde also mote I thee
(base) Been grete wardeyns vpon chastitee
(base) But nathelees syn I knowe youre delit
(base) I shal fulfille youre worldly appetit
(base) Chees now quod she oon of thise thynges tweye
(base) To han me foul and old til that I deye
(base) And be to yow a trewe humble wyf
(base) And neuere yow displese in al my lyf
(base) Or ellis ye wol han me yong and fair
(base) And take youre auenture of the repair
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That shal be to youre hous by cause of me
(base) Or in som oother place may wel be
(base) Now chees your seluen wheither that yow liketh
(base) This knyght auyseth hym and soore siketh
(base) But atte laste he seyde in this manere
(base) My lady and my loue and wyf so deere
(base) I putte me in youre wise gouernaunce
(base) Cheseth youre self which that may be moost plesaunce
(base) And moost honour to yow and me also
(base) I do no fors the wheither of the two
(base) For as yow liketh it suffiseth me
(base) Thanne haue I gete of yow maistrye quod she
(base) Syn I may chese and gouerne as me lest
(base) Ye certes wyf quod he I holde it best
(base) Kys me quod she we be no lenger wrothe
(base) For by my trouthe I wol be to yow bothe
(base) This is to seyn ye bothe fair and good
(base) I pray to god that I mote steruen wood
(base) But I to yow be also good and trewe
(base) As euere was wyf syn that the world was newe
(base) And but I be to morn as fair to sene
(base) As any lady Emperice or Queene
(base) That is bitwix the Est and eek the West
(base) Do with my lyf and deth right as yow lest
(base) And so they slepte tyl it was morow gray
(base) And then she sayd when it was day
(base) Cast vp the Curtyn looke how that it is
(base) And whan the knyght say verraily al this
(base) That she so fair was and so yong ther to
(base) For ioye he hente hire in his armes two
(base) His herte bathed in a bath of blisse
(base) A thousand tyme a rewe he gan hir kisse
(base) And she obeyed hym in euery thyng
(base) That myghte do hym plesance or likyng
(base) And thus they lyue vnto hir lyues ende
(base) In parfit ioye and Ihu crist vs sende
(base) Housbondes meke yonge and fressh a bedde
(base) And grace touerbyde hem that we wedde
(base) And eek I praye Ihu shorte hir lyues
(base) That noght wol be gouerned by hir wyues

div.l: (base) Thus seyde oure hoost / and lat hym telle his tale
(base) Now telleth forth / thogh that the Somnour gale
(base) Ne spareth nat myn owene mayster deere
(base) ¶ This false theef this Somnour / quod the frere
(base) Hadde alwey / baudes redy to his hond
(base) As any hauk to lure in Engelond
(base) That tolde hym / al the secree that they knewe
(base) For hire aqueyntance / was nat come of newe
(base) They weren / hise Approwours pryuely
(base) He took hymself / a greet profit ther by
(base) His maister knew nat alwey / what he wan
(base) Withouten mandement a lewed man
(base) He koude somne / on peyne of cristes curs
(base) And they were glade / for to fille his purs
(base) And make hym / grete festes atte nale
(base) And right as Iudas / hadde purses smale
(base) And was a theef right swich a theef was he
(base) His maister / hadde but half his duetee
(base) He was / if I shal yeuen hym his laude
(base) A theef / and eek a somnour / and a baude
(base) He hadde eek wenches / at his retenue
(base) That wheither that sir Robert / or sire hewe
(base) Or Iakke / or Rauf or who so that it were
(base) That lay by hem / they tolde it in his ere
(base) Thus was the wenche and he / of oon assent
(base) And he wolde fecche / a feyned mandement
(base) And somne hem to Chapitre / bothe two
(base) And pile the man / and lete the wenche go
(base) ¶ Thanne wolde he seye / freend I shal for thy sake
(base) Do stryke hire / out of oure lettres blake
(base) Thee thar namoore / as in this cas trauaille
(base) I am thy freend / ther I thee may auaille
(base) Certeyn / he knew of bryberyes mo
(base) Than possible is / to telle in yeres two
(base) For in this world / nys dogge for the bowe
(base) That kan an hurt deer / from an hool knowe
(base) Bet than this somnour / knew a sly lecchour
(base) Or an Auouter / or a paramour
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And for that was / the fruyt of al his rente
(base) Therfore on it / he sette al his entente
(base) ¶ And so bifel / that ones on a day
(base) This Somnour / euere waityng on his pray
(base) For to somne an old wydewe / a Ribibe
(base) Feynynge a cause / for he wolde brybe
(base) Happed / that he say / bifore hym ryde
(base) And saw be fore hym a man ride
(base) A gay yeman / vnder a Forest syde
(base) A bowe he bar / and arwes brighte and kene
(base) He hadde vpon / a courtepy of grene
(base) An hat vpon his heed / with frenges blake
(base) ¶ Sire quod this Somnour / hayl / and wel atake
(base) ¶ Wel come quod he / and euery good felawe
(base) Where ridestow / vnder this grene shawe
(base) Seyde this yeman / wiltow fer to day
(base) ¶ This Somnour hym answerde / and seyde nay
(base) Here faste by quod he / is myn entente
(base) To ryden / for to reysen vp a rente
(base) That longeth / to my lordes duetee
(base) ¶ Artow thanne a Bailly ; / ye quod he
(base) He dorste nat for verray filthe and shame
(base) Seye that he was a Somnour / for the name
(base) ¶ Depardieux quod this yeman / deere brother
(base) Thow art a bailly / and I am another
(base) I am vnknowen / as in this contree
(base) Of thyn aqueyntance / I wolde praye thee
(base) And eek of bretherhede / if that yow leste
(base) I haue gold / and siluer in my cheste
(base) ¶ If that thee happed / to come in oure shire
(base) Al shal be thyn / right as thow wolt desire
(base) ¶ Graunt mercy quod this Somnour / by my feith
(base) Euerich in ootheres hond / his trouthe leyth
(base) For to be sworn bretheren / til they deye
(base) In daliaunce / they ryden forth and pleye
(base) And with that worde they redyn forthe hir weye
(base) ¶ This Somnour / which that was / as ful of Iangles
(base) As ful of venym / been thise waryangles
(base) And euere enqueryng vpon euery thyng
(base) Brother quod he / where is now youre dwellyng
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Another day / if that I sholde yow seche
(base) This yeman hym answerde / in softe speche
(base) ¶ Brother quod he / fer in the North contree
(base) Where as I hope / som tyme I shal thee see
(base) Er we departe / I shal thee so wel wisse
(base) That of myn hous / ne shaltow neuere mysse
(base) ¶ Now brother quod this Somnour / I yow preye
(base) Teche me / whil that we ryden by the weye
(base) Syn that ye been a Baillyf / as am I
(base) Som subtiltee / and tel me feithfully
(base) In myn office / how I may moost wynne
(base) And spareth nat for conscience ne synne
(base) But as my brother / tel me how do ye
(base) ¶ Now by my trouthe / brother deere / seyde he
(base) As I shal tellen thee / a feithful tale
(base) My wages been / ful streyte / and ful smale
(base) My lord is hard to me / and daungerous
(base) And myn office / is ful laborous
(base) And therfore / by extorcions I lyue
(base) For sothe I take / al that men wol me yeue
(base) Algate / by sleighte / or by violence
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / I wynne al my dispence
(base) I kan no bettre tellen / feithfully
(base) ¶ Now certes quod this Somnour / so fare I
(base) I spare nat to taken / god it woot
(base) But it be to heuy / or to hoot
(base) What I may gete / in conseil priuely
(base) No manere conscience / of that haue I
(base) Nere myn extorcioun / I myghte nat lyuen
(base) Ne of swiche Iapes / wol I nat be shryuen
(base) Stomak ne Conscience / ne knowe I noon
(base) I sherewe / thise Shryftesfadres euerychon
(base) Wel be we met by god / and by seint Iame
(base) But leeue brother / tel me thanne thy name
(base) Quod this Somnour / in this mene whyle
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This yeman / gan a litel for to smyle
(base) ¶ Brother quod he / woltow that I thee telle
(base) I am a feend / my dwellyng is in helle
(base) And here I ryde / aboute my purchasyng
(base) To wite / wher men wolde yeue me any thyng
(base) My purchas / is theffect of al my rente
(base) Looke how thow rydest for the same entente
(base) To wynne good / thow rekkest neuere how
(base) Right so fare I / for ryde wold I now
(base) Vnto the worldes ende / for a preye
(base) ¶ A quod this Somnour / benedicite what sey ye
(base) I wende / ye were a yeman trewely
(base) Ye han a mannes shap / as wel as I
(base) Han ye a figure thanne / determynat
(base) In helle ther ye been / in youre estat
(base) ¶ Nay certeynly quod he / ther haue we noon
(base) But whan vs liketh / we kan take vs oon
(base) Or ellis make yow seme / we ben shape
(base) Som tyme / lyk a man / or lyk an Ape
(base) Or lyk an Aungel / kan I ryde or go
(base) It is no wonder thyng theigh it be so
(base) A lousy Iogelour / kan deceyue thee
(base) And pardee yet kan I / moore craft than he
(base) ¶ Whi quod this Somnour / ryde ye thanne or goon
(base) In sondry shap / and nat alwey in oon
(base) ¶ For we quod he / wol vs swiche formes make
(base) As moost able is / oure preyes for to take
(base) ¶ What maketh yow / to han al this labour
(base) ¶ Ful many a cause / leue sire Somnour
(base) Seyde this feend / but alle thyng hath tyme
(base) The day is short / and it is passed pryme
(base) And yet ne wan I no thyng in this day
(base) I wol entende / to wynnyng if I may
(base) And nat entende / oure wittes to declare
(base) For brother myn / thy wit is al to bare
(base) To vnderstonde / althogh I tolde hem thee
(base) But for thow axest why labouren we
(base) For som tyme / we been goddes Instrumentz
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And meenes / to doon his comandementz
(base) Whan that hym list / vpon his creatures
(base) In diuers art and in diuerse figures
(base) Withouten hym / we han no myght certayn
(base) If that hym lyst to stonde ther agayn
(base) And som tyme / at oure preyere / han we leue
(base) Oonly the body / and nat the soule greue
(base) Witnesse on Iob / whom that we diden wo
(base) And som tyme / han we myght of bothe two
(base) This is to seyn / of soule and body eke
(base) And som tyme / be we suffred for to seke
(base) Vpon a man / and do his soule vnreste
(base) And nat his body / and al is for the beste
(base) Whan he with standeth / oure temptacioun
(base) It is / a cause / of his sauacioun
(base) Al be it that it was / nat oure entente
(base) He sholde be sauf but that we wolde hym hente
(base) He shold be saaf by goddis Iugement
(base) And somtyme / be we seruant vnto man
(base) As to the Erchebisshop / Seint Dunstan
(base) And to the Apostles / seruant eek was I
(base) ¶ Yet tel me / quod the Somnour feithfully
(base) Make ye yow newe bodyes / thus alway
(base) Of Elementz / the feend answerde nay
(base) Som tyme we feyne / and som tyme we aryse
(base) With dede bodyes / in ful sondry wyse
(base) And speke as renably / and faire and wel
(base) As to the Phitonissa / dide Samuel
(base) And yet wol som men seye / it was nat he
(base) I do no fors / of youre dyuynytee
(base) But o thyng warne I thee / I wol nat Iape
(base) Thow wolt algates wite / how we be shape
(base) Thow shalt her afterwardes / my brother deere
(base) Come there / thee nedeth nat of me to lere
(base) For thow shalt by thyn owene experience
(base) Konne in a chayer / rede of this sentence
(base) Bet than Virgile / whil he was on lyue
(base) Or Dant also / now lat vs ryde blyue
(base) Or daūnt also whils he was on lyue
(base) For I wol holde / compaignye with thee
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Til it be so / that thow forsake me
(base) ¶ Nay quod this Somnour / that shal nat bityde
(base) I am a yeman / knowen is ful wyde
(base) My trouthe wol I holde / as in this cas
(base) For theigh thow were / the deuel Sathanas
(base) My trouthe wol I holde / to thee my brother
(base) As I am sworn / and ech of vs til oother
(base) For to be trewe brother / in this cas
(base) And bothe we goon / abouten oure purchas
(base) Taak thow thy part what that men wol thee yeue
(base) And I shal myn / thus may we bothe lyue
(base) And if that any of vs / haue moore than oother
(base) Lat hym be trewe / and parte it with his brother
(base) ¶ I graunte quod the deuel / by my fey
(base) And with that word / they ryden forth hir wey
(base) And right at the entryng of the townes ende
(base) To which this Somnour / shoop hym for to wende
(base) They saye a Cart that charged was with hey
(base) Which that a Cartere / droof forth in his wey
(base) Deep was the wey / for which the Carte stood
(base) This Cartere smoot and cryde as he were wood
(base) Hayt Brok hayt Scot what spare ye for the stones
(base) Hayt skot hayt harad hat brok atonys
(base) The feend quod he / yow fecche body and bones
(base) As ferforthly / as euere were ye foled
(base) So muchel wo / as I haue with yow tholed
(base) The deuel haue al / bothe hors and Cart and hey
(base) ¶ This Somnour seyde / heer shul we han a pley
(base) And neer the feend he drogh / as noght ne were
(base) Ful pryuely / and rowned in his ere
(base) Herkne my brother / herkne by thy feith
(base) Herestow nat how that the Cartere seith
(base) Hent it anon / for he hath yeue it thee
(base) Bothe hey / and Cart and eek his caples thre
(base) ¶ Nay quod the deuel / god woot neuer a del
(base) It is nat his entente / trust thow me wel
(base) Axe hym thy self if thow nat trowest me
(base) Or ellys stynt a while / and thow shalt se
(base) ¶ This Cartere / taketh his hors vpon the croupe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And they bigonne / drawen and to stoupe
(base) Heyt now quod he / ther Ihu crist yow blesse
(base) And al his handes werk bothe moore and lesse
(base) That was wel twight myn owene lyard boy
(base) I pray god saue thee / and Seint loy
(base) Now is my Cart out of the slow pardee
(base) ¶ Lo brother quod the feend / what tolde I thee
(base) Heere may ye se / myn owene deere brother
(base) The Carl spak o thyng but he thoghte another
(base) Lat vs go forth / abouten oure viage
(base) Heere wynne I no thyng vpon cariage
(base) ¶ Whan that they coomen / som what out of towne
(base) This Somnour / to his brother gan to rowne
(base) Brother quod he / here woneth an old rebekke
(base) That hadde almoost as leef to lese hir nekke
(base) As for to yeue a peny / of hir good
(base) I wol han twelue pens / thogh that she be wood
(base) Or I wol somne hire / vnto oure office
(base) And yet god woot of hire knowe I no vice
(base) But for thow canst nat as in this contree
(base) Wynne thy cost taak heer ensample of me
(base) This Somnour / clappeth at the wydwes gate
(base) Com out quod he / thow olde viritrate
(base) I trowe thow hast som frere / or preest with thee
(base) ¶ Who clappeth seyde this wyf / benedicitee
(base) God saue yow sire / what is youre swete wille
(base) ¶ I haue quod he / of somonce a bille
(base) Vp peyne of cursyng looke that thow be
(base) To morn / bifore the Erchedeknes knee
(base) Tanswere to the court of certeyn thynges
(base) ¶ Now lord quod she / crist Ihu kyng of kynges
(base) So wisly helpe me / as I ne may
(base) I haue been syk and that ful many a day
(base) I may nat go so fer quod she / ne ryde
(base) But I be deed / so priketh it in my syde
(base) May I nat axe a libel / sire Somnour
(base) And answere there / by my procutour
(base) To swich thyng as men wole opposen me
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Yis quod this Somnour / pay anon lat see
(base) Twelf pens to me / and I wol thee acquyte
(base) I shal no profit han ther by / but lyte
(base) ¶ My Maister hath the profit / and nat I
(base) Com of / and lat me ryden hastily
(base) Yif me .twelue. pens / I may no lenger tarye
(base) ¶ Twelf pens quod she / now lady Seinte Marie
(base) So wisly help me god / out of care and synne
(base) This wyde world / thogh that I sholde wynne
(base) Ne haue I nat twelue pens / with Inne myn hoold
(base) Ye knowen wel / that I am poure and oold
(base) Kythe youre almesse / on me poure wrecche
(base) ¶ Nay thanne quod he / the foule feend me fecche
(base) If I thexcuse / theigh thow shul be spilt
(base) ¶ Allas quod she / god woot I haue no gilt
(base) ¶ Pay me quod he / or by the swete Seinte Anne
(base) As I wol bere awey / thy newe panne
(base) For dette / which thow owest me of oold
(base) Whan that thow madest / thyn housbonde cokewold
(base) I payde at hom / for thy correccioun
(base) ¶ Thow lyxt quod she / by my sauacioun
(base) Ne was I neuere er now / wydwe ne wyf
(base) Somoned vnto youre court in al my lyf /
(base) Ne neuere I nas / but of my body trewe
(base) Vnto the deuel / blak and row of hewe
(base) Yeue I thy body / and my panne also
(base) ¶ And whan the deuel / herde hire cursen so
(base) Vpon hir knees / he seyde in this manere
(base) Now Mabely / myn owene moder deere
(base) Is this youre wyl in ernest / that ye seye
(base) ¶ The deuel quod she / so fecche hym er he deye
(base) And panne and al / but he wol hym repente
(base) ¶ Nay olde stot that is nat myn entente
(base) Quod this Somnour / for to repente me
(base) For any thyng that I haue had of thee
(base) I wolde I hadde thy smok / and euery clooth
(base) ¶ Now brother quod the deuel / be noght wrooth
(base) Thy body and this panne / been myne by right
(base) Thow shalt with me to helle / yet to nyght
(base) Wher thow shalt knowen / of oure pryuetee
(base) Moore / than a maister of dyuynytee
(base) And with that word / this foule feend hym hente
(base) Body and soule / he with the deuel wente
(base) Wher as that Somnours / han hir heritage
(base) And god / that made after his ymage

div.l: (base) And specially abouen euery thyng
(base) Excyted he the peple in his prechyng
(base) To trentals and to yeue for goddes sake
(base) Wher with men myghte holy houses make
(base) Ther as dyuyne seruice is honoured
(base) Nat ther as it is wasted and deuoured
(base) Ne ther it nedeth nat to be yeue
(base) As to possessioners that mowen lyue
(base) Thanked be god in wele and habundaunce
(base) Trentals seyde he deliuereth from penaunce
(base) Hir freendes soules as wel olde as yonge
(base) Ye whan that they been hastily ysonge
(base) Nat for to holde a preest Ioly and gay
(base) He syngeth nat but o masse in a day
(base) Deliuereth out quod he anon the soules
(base) Ful hard it is with flessh hook or with oules
(base) To been yclawed or to brenne or bake
(base) to kepe llȝou fro peynes of feendes blake
(base) Now spede yow hastily for cristes sake
(base) And whan this frere hadde seyd al his entente
(base) With qui cum patre forth his wey he wente
(base) Whan folk in chirche hadde yeue hym what hem leste
(base) He wente his wey no lenger wolde he reste
(base) With scryppe and typped staf ytukked hye
(base) In euery hous he gan to poure and prye
(base) And beggeth Mele and chese or ellis corn
(base) His felawe hadde a staf typped with horn
(base) A peyre of tables al of yuory
(base) And a poyntel polysshed fetisly
(base) And wroot the names alwey as he stood
(base) Of alle folk that yaf hem any good
(base) Ascaunces that he wolde for hem preye
(base) Yif vs a busshel whete Malt or Reye
(base) A goddes kechyl or a tryp of cheese
(base) Or ellis what yow lyst we may nat chese
(base) A goddes half peny or a masse peny
(base) Or yif vs of youre brawn if ye haue eny
(base) A dagon of youre Blanket leeue Dame
(base) Oure suster deere lo heere I write youre name
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Bacoun or boef or swich thyng as ye fynde
(base) A sturdy harlot wente ay hem bihynde
(base) That was hir hostes man and baar a sak
(base) And what men yaf hem leyde it on his bak

Here bygineþ the ꝓprolog of þe clerk of Oxenford
SIre clerk of Oxenford oure oost saide
Ȝe ryde as stille ⁊ coy as doth amaide
Were newe spowsed sittyng at þe bord
This day ne herde I of ȝoure mouth a word
I trowe þat ȝe studie aboute some sophyme
But salamon saith al thing haþ tyme
For goddes sake beth of better chere
It is no tyme now to studie here
Telle vs som mery tale by ȝoure fay
For what man is entred in to play
He nedes moot vnto þat play assente
But prechiþ not as freres done in lente
To make vs for oure olde synnes to wepe
Ne þat thi tale make vs not to slepe
Telle vs som mery thing of auentoures
Ȝoure termes ȝoure figures ⁊ ȝoure coloures
Kepe hem in stoor til so be ȝe hem endite
Heigh stile as when men to kynges write
Spekith so playn at þis tyme I ȝow pray
That we may vnderstonde what ȝe say
This worthi clerk benignely answerde
Oost quod he I am vnder ȝoure ȝerde
Ȝe haue as now of vs þe gouꝰernaūnce
And þꝰerfore wil I doo ȝow obeisaūnce
As fer as resoūn asketh hardily
I wole ȝow telle a tale whiche þat I
Lerned at Padow of a worthi clerk
As ꝓproved by his wordes ⁊ his werk
I dar þe better aske of ȝow a space
Of audience to schewen oure requeste
And ȝe my lord to doon right as ȝow leste
For certes lord so wel vs liketh ȝow
And alle ȝoure and euꝰere han done þat we
Ne coude nought oure owne self devisen how
We myghte more lyue in felicitee
Saue oo thing lord ȝif hit ȝoure wille be
That for to be a wedded man ȝow leste
Than were ȝoure peple in souꝰerayn hertes reste
Boweth ȝoure nekke vnder þat blesful ȝok
Of souꝰeraīngte noght of seruise
Whiche men clepe spousaile or wedlok
And þinketh lord among ȝoure þoghtes wise
That of wedlok cometh grete emprise
For þogh we slepe or wake or rome or ryde
Ay fleeth þe tyme it wole no man abide
And þogh ȝoure grene ȝouthe growe as ȝit
In crepeth age alway as stille as stoon
And deth manaseth euꝰery age ⁊ smyt
In eche estate for þere eskapeth noon
And also certeyn as we knoweþ euꝰerichon
That we schul dye ⁊ vncerteyn þat we alle
Been of þat day þat deth shal on vs falle
Acceptith þan of vs þe trewe entent
That neuꝰere ȝit refuseth ȝoure heste
And we wolen alle lord ȝif ȝe wole assent
Chese ȝow a wyf in schort tyme at þe leste
Boren of þe gentileste and of þe meste
Of al þis lond so þat hit oghte seme
Honour to god ⁊ ȝow so as we can deme
Delyuꝰere vs of al þis busy drede
And take a wyf for hye goddes sake
For ȝif hit be fel so as god for bede
That þorgh ȝoure deth ȝoure lynage schulde aslake
And a straūnnge lynage schulde take
Ȝoure heritage o wo were vs on lyue
Wherfore I pray ȝow hastily to wyue
Here meke prayer ⁊ here pitous chere
Made þe marquis haue suche pitee
Wole ȝe quod he myn owne peple dere
To þat I neuer erst þoghte constreyne me
I me reioyse not of my liberte
That selden tyme is foūnde in mariage
Ther I was free I moot ben in seruage
But naþeles I see ȝoure trewe entente
And truste vpon ȝow ⁊ haue doon ay
Wherfore of my free will I assente
To wedde me as sone as euꝰere I may
But þere as ȝe haue ꝓprofred me to day
To chese me a wyf I ȝow relese
That choys ⁊ pray ȝow of þat ꝓprofre cese
For god it woot þat children ofte ben
Vnlike her worþi eldres hem bifore
Bounte cometh al of god noght of þe streen
Of whiche þei ben engendred ⁊ I bore
I truste in goddes bounte ⁊ þerfore
My mariage ⁊ myn estate ⁊ reste
I him be take he may doo as him leste
Lete me allone in chesynge of my wyf
That charge vpon my bak I wole endure
But I ȝow pray ⁊ charge vpon ȝoure lyf
That wyf þat I take ȝe me ensure
To worschippe hire while my lyf endure
In word and werk bothe here ⁊ elles where
As sche an Empoures doughter were
And ferþꝰermore þis scholen ȝe sweren þat ȝe
Aȝenst my choys schulle neiþer grucche ne stryue
For sithen I schal for goo my liberte
At ȝoure requeste as euer mote I thryue
Ther as myn herte is sette þꝰere wole I wyue
And but ȝe wolen assente in swiche manere
I pray ȝow spekith namore of this matiere
With hertly wille þei sworen ⁊ assenten
To al þis þing þere seide no wight nay
Bysechinge him of grace or þei wenten
That he hem wolde graunten a certeyn day
Of his spousaile as sone as euꝰere he may
For ȝit alway þe puple somwhat dredde
Lest þis marquis wolde no wyf wedde
He graunted hem a day suche as hem leste
On whiche he wolde be wedded sikerly
And saide he dide al this at her requeste
And þei with humble entent ful buxomly
Knelynge vpon her knees ful reuerently
Him thonken alle and thus þei han an ende
Of here entente ⁊ home aȝeyn þei wende
And here vpon he to his officers
Comaūndyng for þe feste to purueie
And to his pryue knightes ⁊ squiers
Suche charge ȝaf hem as he list on hem leye
And þei to his comaūndementz obeie
And eche of hem doth his diligence
To done vnto þe feste reuꝰerence
Noght fer fro thilke place honurable
Where as þis marquis schope his mariage
There stood athroop of sight dilectable
In whiche þose folk of þat vilage
Hadden her bestes and her herbigage
And of her labour toke her sustinaūnce
After þe erthe ȝaf hem habundaūnce
Among this pore folk þere dwelled aman
Whiche þat was holden porest of hem alle
But hye god somtyme sende can
His grace vnto a litel oxe stalle
Ianicula men of that thrope him calle
A doghter hadde he fair ⁊ ȝong of sight
And Grisilde þis ȝonge maide hight
But forto speke of vꝰertuous beaute
Than was sche oon the fairest vnder sonne
Wel pouerly Ifostred was sche
No likerousnesse was in hire lust I ronne
Wel ofter of the welle þan of the tonne
Sche drank ⁊ for sche wolde vertu please
Sche knew wel labour but noon Idel ease
But þogh þis maide were tendre ⁊ ȝonge of aage
Ȝit in the brest of her virginite
Ther was enclosed ripe ⁊ sad corage
And in grete reuꝰerence ⁊ grete charite
Hire olde pouꝰere fader fostred sche
A fewe schepe spynnyng on þe feld sche kepte
Sche wolde not ben Idel til sche slepte
And whan sche homward come sche wolde bringe
Wortes ⁊ herbes tymes ful ofte
Whiche sche shrad and sethe for hire lyuynge
And made hir bedde ful hard ⁊ no thing softe
And ay sche kepte hir fadre lyf on lofte
With euꝰery obeisaunce ⁊ diligence
That child may doo to fadres reuꝰerence
Vpon Grisilde þe pouꝰere creature
Wel ofte haþ marquys sette his eighe
As he an hunting rood ꝑperauenture
And when hit fel þat he myght here aspye
He not with wantowne lokyng of folie
His eighen cast vpon hire but in sad wise
Vpon hir chere he wolde him ofte avise
Comendyng in his herte hire wōmmanhede
And eke her vꝰertu passyng eny wight
Of so ȝonge age as wel in chere as in dede
For þogh the peple haue no grete insight
In vertu he considered ful right
Hir beaute and disposed þat he wolde
Hire wedde if euere he wedde scholde
The day of weddyng come but no wight can
Telle what wōmman hit scholde be
For whiche mervaile wondred many aman
And seiden when þey were in pryuyte
Wol noght oure lord leue his vanite
Wil he noght wedde alas þe while
Why wil he him self ⁊ vs þus begile
But natheles þis marquys haþ do make
Of gemmes sette in gold and of Azure
For þat euere vꝰertuous was sche
Sche was encresed in suche excellence
Of thewes sette in hye bounte
And so discrete ⁊ faire of eloquence
So benigne ⁊ digne of Reuꝰerence
And coude þe peple hertes so embrace
That eche hir loued þat loked on hir face
Noght only of saluce in þat toūn
Pubblisched was þe bounte of hir name
And eke beside in many a regioūn
If one saide wel an other saide the same
So sprad of hir bounte the fame
That men ⁊ wōmmen bothe ȝonge ⁊ olde
Goon to saluce hir to byholde
This walter lowely nay but really
Weddith wiþ fortunat honeste
In goddes pees lyueth wel esily
At home ⁊ outward grace I now had he
And for he sawh vnder lowe degree
Was ofte vertu hid the puple him held
A prudent man ⁊ þat is sene wel seld
Noght only Grisilde þus þurgh hir witte
Coude al þe feete of wyfly homlynesse
But eke wha n þe caas required hit
The comune ꝓprofight couthe sche redresse
Ther nas discord rancour ne heuynesse
In al þe lond þat sche ne coude it cese
And bringe hem alle wisely in reste ⁊ ese
Though þat hire housbonde pꝰersent were or none
Ȝif gentil men or othre of her contre
Were wrothe sche coude bringe hem at one
So wise ⁊ rype wordes hadde sche
And Iugement of so grete equite
That sche fro heuene was sent as men wende
Peple to saue ⁊ euꝰery wrong to amende
Noght longe tyme after þat þis Grisilde
Was wedded sche adoghter hath bore
Al had sche leuꝰere borne a knaue childe
Glad was þis marquys ⁊ his folk þꝰerfore
For þogh amaiden child come al bifore
Sche may to a knaue child atteyne
By liklyhede sethyns sche is not bareyne
Therfore as hit falleth tymes mo
Whan þis childe haþ souked but aþrowe
This marquys in his herte longeth so
To tempte his wyf hir sadnes to knowe
That he myghte fro his herte þrowe
This merveilous desire his wyf to assay
Natheles god woot he þoghte hir affray
He hadde assaied hire I now byfore
And fonde hir euer good what nedeth hit
Hir forto tormente ⁊ alway more ⁊ more
Thogh some men preise hit for a subtil wit
But as for me I say þat euel hit sitte
To assay a wyf whan hit is no nede
And putten her in angwische ⁊ in drede
For whiche þis marquys wroght on this manere
He come anyght allone þere as sche lay
With sterne face ⁊ trouble chere
And saide thus Grisilde quod he þat day
That I ȝow toke out of ȝoure pouꝰere aray
And putte ȝow in estate of hye noblesse
Ȝe han not forgeten as I gesse
I say Grisilde þis pꝰersent dignite
In whiche I haue putte ȝow as I trowe
Maketh not ȝow forȝetful forto be
That I ȝow took in pouꝰere estate ful lowe
For any þing ȝe mote ȝoure seluen knowe
Take hede of euꝰery word þat I ȝow say
Ther is no wight þat herith þis but we tway
Ȝe wote ȝoure self wel how þat ȝe come here
Into þis hous hit is not longe agoo
And þogh to me ȝe be leef ⁊ dere
Vnto my gentiles ȝe be no þing so
Thei say to hem hit is grete schame ⁊ woo
Forto be sugette ⁊ in seruage
To the þat art borne of so lowe lynage
And namely sithen þi doghter was bore
Thise wordes han þei spoke douteles
But I desire as I haue done bifore
To lyue my lyf with hem in reste ⁊ pees
I may not in this caas be recheles
I moste doo with thi doghter for þe beste
Noght as I wolde but as my gentiles leste
And ȝit god woot this is wel loth to me
But natheles wiþ oute ȝoure wityng
I wil not doo but þis I wil quod he
Þat ȝe to me assente as in this þing
Scheweþ now ȝoure pacience in ȝoure worching
That ȝe me behight ⁊ swore in ȝoure vilage
That day þat maked was oure mariage
Whan sche had herd al this sche was not amoved
Neither in word or chere or contynaūnce
For as hit semed sche was not agreued
Sche seide lord al lieth in ȝoure plesaūnce
My child ⁊ I wiþ hertly obeisaunce
Ben ȝoures alle ⁊ ȝe may saue ⁊ spille
Ȝoure awne thing wheþꝰer þat ȝe wille
Ther may no thing so god my soule saue
Be likyng to ȝow þat may displese me
Ne I desire no þyng to haue
Ne drede to lese saue only ȝe
This wil is in myn herte ⁊ ay schal be
No lengþe of tyme or deth it may deface
Neither chaūnge my corage in to oþer place
Glad was þe marquys for hir answeryng
But ȝit he feyned as he were not so
Al drery was his chere ⁊ his lokyng
When he schulde out of þe chambre goo
Sone after þis a forlong wey or two
He pleynly haþ told his entente
Vnto aman whiche he to his wyf sente
Amanꝰere seriaunt was this prdue man
The whiche þat he feithful foūnden hadde
In thynges grete and eke suche folk wel can
Doon execucioūn of thinges badde
The lord knewe wel þat he him loued ⁊ dradde
And whan þis sergeant wiste his lordes wille
In to the chambre hestalked him ful stille
Madame he seide ȝe mote forȝeue it me
Though I doo thing to whiche I am constreyned
Ȝe ben so wise þat wel knowe ȝee
That lordes hestes may not be feyned
They mowen wel be wayled ⁊ compleyned
But men mote nede vnto her lust obeie
And so wole I there is no more to seie
That child I am comaūnded to take
And spak na more but out þe child he hente
Despitously and gan achere make
As he wolde han slayn him or he wente
Grisilde mote al suffre ⁊ al consente
And as a lombe sche sitteth meke ⁊ stille
And lete þis cruel sergeant haue his wille
Suspecte was the fame of this man
Suspecte his fame suspecte his word also
Suspecte the tyme þat he þis bygan
For his doughter þat sche loued so
Sche wende he wolde haue slayn it right tho
But natheles sche neither wept ne siked
Conformynge hir to þat the marquys liked
And at þe laste speke sche bygan
And mekely to þe sergeant preide
So as he was a worthi gentil man
That sche moste kisse hir child or þat it deide
And in hir barme þis litel child sche leide
With ful sadde face ⁊ gan her child to blisse
And lulled it ⁊ after gan it kisse
And þus sche saide in hire benigne voys
Fare wel my child I shal þe neuꝰere see
But sithen I haue marked þe with þe croys
Of þilke fader I blessed mote þou bee
That for vs deide vpon þe rode tree
Thi soule litel child I him bytake
For this nyght schalt þou deien for my sake
I trowe þat to a Norice in this caas
Hit hadde ben þis rewthe for to see
Wel myght a moder þan crie alas
But natheles so sad stedfast was sche
That sche endured al hir aduꝰersite
And to the sergeant mekely sche saide
Haue here a ȝayn þis litel ȝonge maide
And goth now quod sche and doth my lordes heste
And oo thing wolde I pray ȝow of ȝoure grace
That but my lord forbede ȝow at þe leste
Burieth this litel body in some place
That no bestes ne briddes hit to Race
But he no word to þe purpos wolde say
But toke the child ⁊ wente vpon his way
This sergeant come to þe lord a gayn
And of Grisildes wordes and of hir chere
He tolde him poynt fro poynt in schort ⁊ playn
And him persentid with his doghter dere
Somwhat þis lord had routhe in his manere
But natheles his purpos helde he stille
As lordes done whan þei wil haue her wille
And bad þis sergeant ful prduely
He schulde wel oofte þis child wynde ⁊ wrappe
Wiþ al circumstaunces tendirly
And carie hit in a coffre or in a lappe
But vp peyne his heed of forto swappe
That no man scholde knowe of his entent
Ne whennes he come ne whider þat he went
But at Boloyne to his suster dere
That þo of pavye was Countesse
He schulde hir take ⁊ schewe hir þis matere
Beseching hir to done hire busynesse
This child to fostre in al gladnesse
And whos child þat hit was he bad hire hide
From euꝰery wight for oght þat myght betide
This sergeant goth ⁊ haþ fulfilled this thing
But to þe Marquys now retorne we
For now goþ he wel ofte ymagynyng
If by his wyf he myghte see
And by her wordes ꝑperceyue þat sche
Were chaūnged but he coude neuꝰere fynde
But euere in oon I like sad ⁊ kynde
As glad as humble as besy in seruice
And eke in loue as sche was wont to be
Was sche to him in euꝰery manꝰerr wise
Ne of hir doghter a word spak sche
None accident for none aduꝰersite
Was seen in hire ne neuꝰere hir doghter name
Nempned sche for ernest ne for game
IN þis estate passed ben foure ȝere
Er sche with childe was but as god wolde
A knave child sche bare by this Waltere
Wel graciously and faire to byholde
And when folk hit to his fader tolde
noght only he but al þe contre merye
Was for þat child and god þei þanke ⁊ herie
When þat it was two ȝere old ⁊ fro þe breste
Departed from his norice on a day
This marquys caught ȝit an oþer leste
To tempten his wyf often if he may
O nedeles was sche tempted in assay
But wedded men knowen no mesure
When þei fynde apacient creature
Wyf quod this marquys ȝe han herd or this
My puple sekely berith oure mariage
And namely sithen my sone borne is
Now is it wors þan euer in oure age
The murmr sleeþ my herte ⁊ my corage

Or elles blak deueles wole hem take
Of other humoures couthe I telle also
Þat werken many aman in slepe ful wo
But I will passen / as lightly as I can
Lo Caton whiche þat was so wise aman
Saide he not þus ne do no force of dremes
Now sire quod sche when we flee fro the bemes
For goddes loue as taketh som laxatyf
Vp ꝑperil of my soule and of my lyf
I coūnseile ȝow þe beste I wil not lye
That bothe of colre ⁊ of malencolie
Ȝe purge ȝow and for ȝe schul not tarie
Thogh þat in þis toūn is none apoticarie
I schal my self to herbes techen ȝow
Þat schal be ȝoure hele ⁊ ȝoure prow
And in the gardyn tho herbes schal I fynde
The whiche han of her ꝓproprete by kynde
To purgen ȝow bynethe ⁊ eke aboue
Forȝetith not þis for goddes owne loue
Ȝe ben ful colryk of complexioūn
Where þe sonne in his ascencioūn
Ne fynde ȝow replete of ȝoure humoures hote
And if it doo I dar wel leie a grote
Þat ȝe schul haue a feuer tercian
Or an agu þat may be ȝoure ban
A day or two ȝe schul haue digestyues
Of wormes or ȝe take ȝoure laxatyues
Of laureal Centaure ⁊ of fumytere
Or elles of Ellebore þat groweth þere

Of herbe yve growynge in oure ȝerd þꝰere merye is
Pek hem vp right as þey growe ⁊ ete hem yn
Be murie housbonde for ȝoure fadres kyn

Madame quod he graunt mꝰercy of ȝoure lore
But natheles as touching daun Catoūn
Þat haþ of wisdom suche grete renoūn
By god men may in olde bokes rede
Oon of þe grettest auctour out of drede
Of many aman more of auctorite
Then euer Catoūn was so mote I the
That all þe reuꝰerse sayn of þis sentence
And han wel founden by exꝑperience
That dremes ben significacioūns
As wel of ioye as of tribulacioūns
That folk endure in this lyf present
Ther nedeth not to make of þis non argument
The vꝰerray preef scheweth it in dede
Oon of þe grettest auctour out of drede
Saith þus þat whylom two felawes went
On pilgimage in ful good entent
And happed so thei comen in to a toūn
Where as þꝰere was suche congregacioūn
Of peple and eke of streight herbygate
That þei fand as moche as a cotage
In whiche þei bothe myght I logged be
Wherfore they mosten of necessite
As for þat nyght deꝑperten of companye
And eche of hem goth in to his hostelrie
And toke his logging as it wolde falle
That oon of hem was logged in a stalle
Fer in a yerd wiþ Oxen of þe plowh
That oþer man was logged wel I nowh
As was his auenture or his fortune
That vs gouꝰerneth all as in comune
And so byfel longe er hit were day
This man mette in his bed ther as he lay
How þat his felawe gan on hym calle
And saide allas for in an Oxe stalle
This myght schal I be murdred there I lye
Now helpe me dere brother or I dye
In all haste come to me he saide
This man out of his slepe for fere abraide
But when þat he was wakned out of his slepe
He torneth hym ⁊ took of this no kepe
Him þoghte his dreme was noght but a vanite
Thus twies in his slepynge dremed he
And at þe thridde tyme ȝit his felawe
Come as he þoghte I am now I slawe
Byholde my blody woūndes depe ⁊ wyde
Arise vp erly in the morwe tide
And at þe west gate of þe toūn quod he
A cartful of dong þꝰere schalt þou see
In whiche his body is hyd ful piriuely
Do þilke carte aresten boldely
My gold caused my mordre soth to sayn
And tolde him euꝰery poynt how he was slayn
With a ful pitous face pale of hewe
And truste wel his dreem he fond ful trewe
For on the morne as sone as it was day
To his felawes yn he toke the way
And when he come to þis Oxe stalle
After his felawe he bygan to calle
The Osteler answerd him anon
And saide sire ȝoure felawe is goon
As sone as day he went out of the toūn
This man gan falle in grete suspecioūn
Remēmbrynge on his dremes þat he mette
And forth he goth no lenger wolde he lette
Vnto þe west gate of þe toūn ⁊ fond
A donge carte as he wente to donge þe lond
That was arrayed in þe same wise
As ȝe han herd the dede man devise
And with an hardy herte be gan to crye
Veniaūnce ⁊ Iustice of this vilonye
My felawe murdred is þis same nyght
And in this Carte he lieth gapyng vp right
The dede man þat murdred was all newe
O blisful god þat art so Iust ⁊ trewe
Lo how þat þou be wreyest murdre alway
Murdre wole out þat see we day be day
Mordre is so wlatsom and so abhominable
To god þat is so Iust and resonable
That he ne wole not suffred heled be
Theigh it abide a ȝeer or two or thre
Murdre wole out þis is myn conclusioūn
And right anon mynistres of þe toūn
Haþ hent þe carter and so sore hym peyned
And eke the Osteler so fer engyned
That þei be knewe her wikkednes anoon
And weren honged by þe nekke boon
Here may men see þat dremes ben to drede
And certes in the same boke I rede
Right in the nexte chapitre I rede of þis
I gabbe not so haue I ioye or blis
Two men þat wolde haue passed the see
For certeyn cause in to a fer contree
If þat þe wynd ne hadde be contrarie
That made hem in a citee for to tarie
That stood ful merye vpon an hauen side
But on a day aȝenst þe euen tide
The wynd gan chaūnge ⁊ blew as hem leste
Iolyf ⁊ glad thei wenten vnto reste
And casten hem ful erly forto saile
But herkene how þat oo man fel in grete ꝑperaile
That oon of hem in slepyng as he lay
Hym mette a wonder dreem aȝenst the day
Hym þoght a man stood by his beddis side
And him comaūnded þat he schulde abide
And saide him þus if þou to morwe wende
Thou schalt be dreynt my tale is at an ende
He woke ⁊ tolde his felawe þat he mette
For when I see þe beaute of ȝoure face
Ȝe ben so scarlet reed aboute ȝoure eighen
Hit makith all my drede forto dyen
For also siker as Inpirincipio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame þe sentence of þis latyn is
Wōmman is mannes ioye ⁊ his blis
For when I fele on nyght ȝoure softe side
Al be hit þat I may not on ȝow ride
For þat oure ꝑperche is made so narwe alas
I am so full of ioye ⁊ solas
That I defie bothe sweuene ⁊ dreem
And with þat word I fleigh doūn fro þe beem
For it was day and eke his hennes alle
And with a chukke he gan hem forto calle
For he hadde founde a corn lay in þe ȝerd
Royal he was no more a ferd
He fetherid ꝑpertelote twenty tyme
And trad as ofte er it was pryme
He lokeþ as it were agrym lyoūn
And on his toos he romed vp ⁊ doūn
Him deigned not to sette his feet on groūnde
Ay chukked he whan he had acorn I foūnde
And to him þanne ran his wyfes alle
Thus royal as a prince in his halle
Leue I this chaūnteclere in his pasture
And after wole I telle of his auenture
When þe monthe in whiche þe world bygan
That highte marche when god firste made man
Was complete and passed were also
Sithens Marche by gan thritty dayes ⁊ two
Byfel þat chauntecler in his pride
His seuen wyfes walkyng him be side
Cast vp his eighen to þe bright sonne
That in þe signe of Taurus was ronne
Twenty degrees ⁊ oon ⁊ somwhat more
He knew by kynde ⁊ by none oþꝰer lore
Þat it was pirime he krew wiþ blisful steuene
The sonne he saide is clomben vp on heuene
Fourty degrees ⁊ oon ⁊ more I wys
Madame ꝑpertelote my worldes blis
Herkene how þese blisful briddes synge
And see the fresche floures how þei spiringe
Ful is myn herte of reuel ⁊ of solas
But sodenly him fel a sorwful caas
For euꝰere þe latter ende of ioye is sone a goo
And comonly ofte tyme it fallith so
And if Arthour couthe faire endite
He in a cronicle myght sauely write
As for a souꝰerayn notabilite
Now euꝰery wise man herkene me
This storye is as trewe I vndertake
As is the book of launcelot de lake
That wōmmen held in ful greet reuꝰerence
Now wol I torne aȝeyn to my sentence
A Col foxe full of sleight ⁊ iniquite
That in the groue had woned ȝeres thre
By highe ymaginacioūn a forn caste
The same nyght þurgh out þe hogges braste
Into þe ȝerd there chaūnteclere þe faire
Was wont ⁊ eke his wifes to repayre
And in abed of wortes stille he lay
Til it was passed vnderne of þe day
Waytinge his tyme on chauntecler to falle
As gladly done þese homycides alle
That in a wayte ligge to murdre men
O false murdrorur roukynge in thi den
O newe scariot and newe Geniloūn
False dissimulorur oo greke synoūn
That broghtest troye all vtterly to sorwe
O chauntecler a cursed be þat morwe
Þat þou into þe ȝerd fleigh fro þe bemes
Thou were ful wel I warned be þi dremes
Þat ilke day was ꝑperilous to the
But þat as god afore woot mote nedes be
After the opynyoūn of certeyn clerkes
Witnes on him þat any clerk is
That in scole grete altercacioūn
In this mater ⁊ grete disputacioūn
And haþ ben of an hondred þowsand men
But I ne can bulte it all to bren
As can the holy doctour augustyn
Or Boece or þe bisshop Bradwardyn
Whether þat goddes will afore wetyng
Streyneth me nedely for to doo athing
Nedely clepe I simple necessite
Or elles ȝif the fre choys be graūnted me
To do þat same þing or doo it noght
Þogh god forwote it or it was wroght
Or of his wetyng streyneth neuꝰere a del
But by necessite condicionell
I wole not haue to done of suche matere
My tale is of a Cok as ȝe scholen here
That toke his coūnseil of his wyf wiþ sorwe
To walken in the ȝerd vpon þe morwe
Þat he hadde mette þe dreme þat I ȝow tolde
Wymen coūnseil be ful ofte colde
Wymmens coūnseil broght vs ferst to wo
And made Adam fro paradys to goo
Ther as he was full merye and well at ese
But for I not whom I myght displese
If I coūnseil of wōmmen wolde blame
Passe ouer for I saide it in my game
Rede auctoures where þei trete of suche matere
My tale is of a cok as ȝe scholen here
These ben þe Cokkes wordes ⁊ not myne
I can no harme of no wōmman devyne
Faire in þe sond to bathe hir murily
Lieth ꝑpertilote and all hir sustres by
Aȝen þe sonne ⁊ chaūnteclere so free
Sang merier þan þe mermaide in þe see
For phisialogus saith witterly
How þat þei singen wel and merily
And so bifel as he cast his eighe
Amonges þe wortes vpon a butterflye
He was war of þis foxe þat lay ful lowe
No thing ne luste him þan forto crowe
But cryed anon cok cok ⁊ vp he sterte
As aman þat was affrayed in his herte
For naturelly a best desireth to flee
Fro his contrarie ȝif he may it see
They he neuꝰere hadde seie it erst with his eighe
This chaūntecler when he him gan a spye
He wolde haue fled But þat the fox anon
Saide gentil sire allas what wole ȝe don
Ben ȝe affrayed of me þat am ȝoure frend
Certes sire þan be ȝe vnhend
Ȝif I to ȝow wole harme or vilanye
I am not come ȝoure coūnseil to aspye
But trewely the cause of my comyng
Was only to herkene how þat ȝe syng
For trewely ȝe han as merye asteuene
As angel haþ þat is in heuene
Therwith ȝe han of musyk more felyng
Þan hadde boys or any þat can syng
Myn lord ȝoure fader god his soule blisse
And eke ȝoure moder of hir gentilnesse
Han in myn hous I ben to ȝow grete ese
And certes sire right fayn wolde I ȝow plese
But for men spekith of synging I wol seie
So mote I brouke myn eighen tweie
Saue ȝe I ne herde neuꝰere man so synge
As dede ȝoure fader in þe mornynge
Certes it was of herte al þat he song
And forto make his voys the more strong
He wolde so peyne him þat with boþe his eighen
He moste wynke so loude he dede cryen
And stonden on his tiptos þꝰere wiþ al
And strecche forth his nekke longe ⁊ smal
And eke he was of suche discrecioūn
That þere nas no man in no regioūn
Þat him in song or wisdom myght passe
I haue wel rad daun burnell þꝰere asse
Among his vers þꝰere was a Cok
For a preostes sone ȝaf him a knok
Vpon his legge while he was ȝonge ⁊ nyce
He made him for to lese his benefice
But certeyn þꝰere is none comparisoūn
Bytwixe the wisdom ⁊ discrecioūn
Of ȝoure fader and of his subtillite
Now singeth sire for seint charite
Let see can ȝe ȝoure fader coūnterfete
This chaūntecler his wynges gan to bete
As man þat coude not his tresoūn a spye
So was he ravisshed in his flaterie
Allas ȝe lordes many a false Flatour
Is in ȝoure court ⁊ many a losengour
That plesen ȝow more be my feith
Than he þat sothfastnes vnto ȝow seith
Redith eccliastre of flaterie
Beth war ȝe lordes of her treccherie
This chaūntecler stood hye vpon his toos
Strecchinge his nekke ⁊ helde his eighen cloos
And gan to crowe lowde for the nones
And daun Russel sterte vp all attones
And by the gargage hente chaunteclere
And on his bak to ward the wode him beer
For ȝit was þere no man him sewed
O destenye þat maist not ben eschewed
Alas þat chaunteclere fel fro þe bemes
Alas his wyf ne roght noght of dremes
And on a friday fel all þis meschaūnce
O venus þat art goddes of plesaūnce
Sithens þat þi seruant was þis chaūnteclere
And in thi seruice dede all his powere
More for delite þen the world to multiplye
Whi woldest þou suffre him on thi day to dye
O gaufrede dere maister souꝰeraigne
Þat whan the worthi kyng Richard was slayne
With schot complaynedest his deth so sore
Why ne hadde I now thi sentence ⁊ thi lore
The friday forto chide as dede ȝe
For on a friday schortly slayn was he
Than wolde I schewe how þat I coude playne
For chaūntecler and for his payne
Certes suche cry ne lamentacioūn
Was of ladies made whan þat ylioūn
Was wonne ⁊ pirrus with his streight swerd
When he hent kyng pryam by þe berd
And slayn him as seide envidos
As maden alle þe hennes in þe clos
When þey hadde seye of chaunteclere þe sight
But souꝰeraynly dame ꝑpertelote schrite
Wel lowder þen ded hasdrubaldes wyf
When þat hire housbonde had lost his lyf
And þat the Romayns had brend Cartage
Sche was so ful of torment ⁊ of rage
That wilfully into þe fuyre sche sterte
And brende hir self wiþ a stedfast herte
O woful hennes right so crieden ȝe
As when þat Nero brend þe citee
Of Rome crieden the senatoures wyfes
For þat her housbondes schulde lese her lyfes
With outen gilt Nero haþ hem slayn
Now wol I torne to my tale aȝayn
This sely widowe and hir doghtres two
Herden the hennes crien ⁊ maken wo
And oute at þe dore sterten þei anon
And sawh þe fox toward þe groue goon
And bare vp his bak þe cok away
And criden out harrow ⁊ weilaway
A ha þe fox ⁊ after him þei ran
And eke with staves many an oþꝰer man

Ran kow and calf ⁊ eke þe vꝰerray hogges
So aferd for berkynge of dogges
And showtyng of men ⁊ of wōmmen eke

and here bygynith þe ꝓprologe of þe ꝑpersoūn
By þat the manciple had his tale ended
Þe sonne fro the south side is discendid
So lowe þat he was noght to my sight
Degrees . xxxixtiri as of hight
Ten of the Clokke hit was so as I gesse
For xj . foot a litel more or lesse
My schadue was at þilke tyme as there
Of suche feet as my lengþe parted were
In sex foot equal of ꝓproporcioūn
Ther with þe mones exaltacioūn
I mene libra / alwey gan ascende
As we were entringe at athropes ende
For wiþ oure Oste as he was wont to gye
As in þis caas oure ioly companye
Saide in þis wise lordinges euꝰerichon
Now lakketh vs no tale more þan oon
Fulfilled is my sentence ⁊ my degree
Who wil now telle a tale lat see
Almost fulfilled is myn ordynaūnce
I pray to god so ȝeue him right good chaūnce
That tellith his tale to vs lustely
Sire preost quod he art þou a vicary
Or art þou a ꝑpersou say soth by þi fay
Be what þou be ne breke noght oure play
For euꝰery man sauf þou haþ told his tale
Vnbocle ⁊ schewe vs what is in thy male
For trewely me þinketh be thyn chere
Thow schuldest knette vp wel a grete matere
Telle vs a fable anone for cokkes bones
This ꝑpersoūn answerde all attones
Thou getest fable none I told for me
For poule þat writeth vnto thymothe
Repreuith hem þat wayfen sooþfastnesse
And tellen fables ⁊ suche wrecchidnesse
Whi schulde I schewen draf out of my feste
When I may schewe whete if þat me leste
For whiche I say if þat þu lust to here
Moralite ⁊ vertuous matere
And then þat ȝe wolen ȝeue me audience
I wol ful fayn at cristes reuꝰerence
Don ȝow plesaūnce lefful as I can
But trusteth wel I am a sothryn man
I can not geste rom ram ruf by lettre
Ne god woot ryme holde I but litel bettre
And þꝰerfore if ȝow luste I wol noght glose
I wol ȝow telle amerye tale in prose
To knytte vp all þis feste ⁊ make an ende
And Ihu for his grace wit me sende
To schewe ȝow the wey in this viage

But natheles þis meditacioūn

div.ab: (base) after that they han receyued baptesme

(base) The
thridde defaute is that men fallen in venyal synnes after
hire baptesme fro day to day

(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence
of euery day

(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of
hem is solempne Another is commune and the thridde is priuee

(base) Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as
to be put out of holy chirche in lente for slaughtre of children
and swich manere thyng

(base) Another is whan man hath synned
openly of which synne the fame is openly spoken in the contree
and thanne holy chirche by Iugement destreyneth hym for to
doon open penance

(base) Commune penaunce is that preestes enioynen
men communly in certeyn cas as for to goon parauenture naked in
pilgrymage or barefoot

(base) Pryuee penaunce is thilke that men
doon al day for priuee synnes of whiche we shryue vs pryuely
and receyue pryuee penance

(base) Now shaltow vnderstande
what bihoueth and is necessarie to verray parfit penitence and
this stant on iij thynges

(base) Contricioun of herte Confessioun of
Mouth and Satisfaccioun

(base) for which seith Seint Iohn Grisostomus
Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym
is enioyned with contricioun of herte and shrift of Mowithhe with satisfaccioun and in wirkynge of alle manere humylitee

(base) and this is
fruytful penitence agayn iij thynges in whiche we wrathe oure
lord Ihesu crist
(base) this is to seyn by delit in thynkynge by recchelesnesse in spekynge by wikked synful wirkynge

(base) and agayns
thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree

(base) The roote of this tree is contricioun that hideth hym in the herte of
hym that is verray repentant right as the roote of a tree hideth
hym in the erthe

(base) Of the roote of Contricioun spryngeth a stalke
that bereth branches and leues of confessioun and fruyt of satisfaccioun

(base) for which crist seith in his gospel dooth digne fruyt
of penitence for by this fruyt may men kNowe this tree and
nat by the roote that is hyd in the herte of man ne by the branches ne the leues of Confessioun

(base) And therfore oure Lord Ihesu crist
seith thus by the fruyt of hem shul ye kNowe hem
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.

(base) Of this
roote eek spryngeth a Seed of grace the which Seed is moder
of Sikernesse and this Seed is egre and hoot

(base) the grace of thys
Seed spryngeth of god thurgh remembrance on the day of dome
and on the peynes of helle

(base) Of this matere seith Salomon that
in the drede of god man forleteth his synne

(base) the hete of thys
seed is the loue of god and the desirynge of the Ioye pardurable

(base) this hete draweth the herte of man to god and dooth hym hate
his synne

(base) for soothly ther is no thyng that sauoureth so wel
to a child as the mylk of his norice ne no thyng is to hym
moore abhomynable than thilke mylk whan it is medled with
oother mete

(base) right so the synful man that loueth his synne
hym semeth it is to hym moost swete of any thyng

(base) but fro that
tyme that he loueth sadly oure lord Ihesu crist and desireth the lyf
pardurable ther nys to hym no thyng moore abhomynable

(base) for soothly the lawe of god is the loue of god for which
Dauid the prophete seith I haue loued thy lawe and hated wikkednesse and hate he that loueth god kepeth his lawe and his word

(base) this tree saugh the prophete Daniel in Spirit vp on the auysion of
Nabugodonosor whanne he conseiled hym to do penitence

(base) Penance is the tree of lyf to hem that it receyuen and he that holdeth
hym in verray penitence is blessed after the Sentence of Salomon

(base) In this penitence or Contricioun man shal vnderstonde
iiij thynges that is to seyn what is Contricioun and whiche
ben the causes that moeuen a man to Contricioun and how he
sholde be contrit and what Contricioun auaileth to the soule

(base) thanne
is it thus that Contricioun is the verray sorwe that a man receyueth
in his herte for hise synnes with sad purpos to shryue hym and to
do penance and neuere moore to do synne

(base) and this sorwe shal ben
in this manere as seith Seint Bernard It shal ben heuy and
greuous and ful sharpe and poynaunt in herte

(base) first for man hath
agilt his lord and his Creatour and moore sharp and poynaunt
for he hath agilt his fader celestial

(base) and yet moore sharpe and
poynaunt for he hath wrathed and agilt hym that boughte hym
that with his precious blood hath delyuered vs fro the bondes of synne and fro the creweltee of the deuel and fro the peynes of helle

(base) The causes

that oghten moeuen a man to Contricioun been vj
ffirst a man shal remembren hym of hise synnes

(base) but looke
that thilke remembrance ne be to hym no delit by no wey but gret
shame and sorwe for his gilt for Iob seith Synful men doon
werkes worthy of Confessioun

(base) And therfore seith Ezechie I
wol remembre me alle the yeris of my lyf in bitternesse of myn
herte

(base) And god seith in the Apocalipes Remembre yow fro whennes that ye ben falle for biforn that tyme that ye synned ye
were the children of god and lymes of the regne of god

(base) but
for youre synne ye ben woxe thral and foul and membres of
the feend hate of Aungeles Sclaundre of holy chirche and
foode of the false serpent perpetuel matere of the fyr of helle

(base) And yet moore foul and abhomynable for ye trespasen so ofte
tyme as dooth the hound that retorneth to ete his spewyng

(base) and
yet be ye fouler for youre longe contynuynge in synne and
youre synful vsage for which ye been roten in youre synne
as a beest in his donge

(base) swiche manere of thoughtes maken
a man haue shame of his synne and no delit as god seyth
by the prophete Ezechiel

(base) ye shal remembre yow of youre
weyes and they shullen displese yow soothly synnes been
the weyes that leden folk to helle

(base) The seconde cause that oghte
make a man to han desdeyn of synne is this that as seith
Seint Peter who so that dooth synne is thral of synne and
synne put a man in greet thraldam

(base) And therfore seith the
prophete Ezechiel I wente sorweful in desdayn of my self
Certes wel oghte a man haue desdayn of synne and with
drawe hym fro that thraldom and vileynye

(base) And lo what
seith Seneca in this matere he seith thus though I wiste
that god neither god ne man ne sholde neuere kNowe it yet
wolde Ihaue desdayn for to do synne

(base) And the same Seneca also
seith Iam born to gretter thynges than to be thral to my body or than for to maken of my body a thral

(base) ne a fouler thral
may no man ne womman make of his body than for to yeue his
body to synne

(base) al were it the fouleste cherl or the fouleste womman
that lyueth and leest of value yet is he thanne moore foul and
moore in seruitute

(base) euere fro the hyer degree that man falleth the
moore is he thral

and moore to god and to the world vil and abhomynable

(base) O goode god wel oghte man haue greet desdayn
of synne sith that thurgh synne ther he was fre Now is he
maked bonde

(base) And ther fore seith Seint Augustyn If thow
hast desdayn of thy seruant if he agilte or synne haue thow
thanne desdayn that thow thy self sholdest do synne

(base) take
reward of thy value that thow ne be to foul to thy self

(base) Allas wel oghten they thanne haue desdayn to ben seruantz
and thralles to synne and soore ben ashamed of hem self

(base) that god
of his endelees goodnesse hath set hem in heigh estat or yeuen hem wit strengthe of body heele beautee prosperitee

(base) and boghte hem fro the deeth with his herte blood that they so
vnkyndely agayns his gentilesse quyten hym so vileynsly
to slawghtre of hir owene soules

(base) O goode god ye wommen that been of so greet beautee remembreth yow of the
prouerbe of Salomon he seith

(base) likneth a fair womman that is
a fool of hire body lyk to a ryng of gold that were in the

(base) for right as a Sowe wroteth in euerich
ordure so wroteth she hire beaute in stynkynge ordure of

(base) The thridde cause that oughte moeue a man to
Contricion is drede of the day of dome and of the horrible peynes of helle

(base) For as Seint Ierome seith At euery
tyme that me remembreth of the day of dome I quake

(base) for
whan I ete and drynke or what so that I do euere semeth
me that the trompe sowneth in myn ere

(base) Riseth ye vp that ben
dede and cometh to the Iugement

(base) O goode god muchel
oghte a man to drede swich a Iugement ther as we shullen ben alle as seith Seint Poul biforn the Sete of oure
lord Ihesu crist
(base) where as he shal maken a general congregacioun where as no man may ben absent

(base) for certes there
ne auaileth noon essoyne ne excusacioun

(base) and nat oonly
that oure defautes shullen be Iuged but eek that alle oure

(base) and as that seith Seint
Bernard ther ne shal no pletynge auaile ne no sleighte We
shullen yeue rekenynge of euerich ydel word

(base) there shul we han
a Iuge that may nat ben deceyued ne corrupt and why for
certes alle oure thoghtes ben descouered as

to hym ne for prayere ne for mede he wol nat ben corrupt

hope to escape

(base) Wherfore as seith Seint Anselme Ful gret
anguisse shullen the synful folk haue at that tyme

shal the stierne and wrothe Iuge sitte aboue and vnder hym

folk shal be the bityng conscience and with oute forth shal

(base) whider shal thanne the wrechched synful man fle to hyde hym certes he may nat hyde hym he moste come forth and shewe hym

seith Seint Ierome the erthe shal caste hym out of hym

(base) Now soothly who so wel
remembreth hym of thise thynges I gesse that his synne

(base) And therfore seith Iob to god Suffre lord that I may a while biwayle and wepe er I go with
oute returnynge to the dirke lond couered with the derknesse of deeth

(base) to the lond of mysese and of derknesse where as
is the shadwe of deeth where as ther is noon ordre or

may ye seen that Iob preyde respit a while to biwepe and

(base) And for as muche as a
man may acquyte hym self biforn god by penitence in

(base) for certes al the sorwe that a man myghte

that Iob

certes the derke light that shal come out of the fyr that euere shal

which god seith by the prophete Ieremye thilke folk that me despisen shulle ben in despit

Honour is eek clepid greet dignytee and heighnesse but in helle
